story:
I just want to photograph the things I love and share those images with the world. It's pretty simple really...

I struggled into my adult years to find My Thing. I fell in love with photography at the ripe old age of 21 and quickly learned that portrait photography was my happy place. It combines two of my favorite things, beautiful faces and beautiful lighting. A good portrait captures the subjects personality, it shows the best side of them and I became addicted to faces!  I do believe that a photo can steal your soul, or at least borrow it for a moment. A photo captures you in a light, in a mood, in a moment that will never exist in that exact equation again. 

Over the years, life has taken it's toll... I've moved so many times in the past 3 years that my equipment is damaged and a bit of an embarrassment. :/ My cat did something to my computer screen which has screwed up the display and so any post-processing has to be done on my boyfriends PC (and I am a MAC user at heart, iLove Apple!). The photograph I have used for this campaign was the last major photo shoot I did, 2 summers ago. That's how long it's been!!! Ouch!  
I am anxious to start creating again using beautiful and fascinating faces, to play with light and textures, to show the world the view through my eyes. You could help me make magic again! And what's life without a little magic?! 

I miss capturing beautiful faces like the sun misses the flower in the depths of winter. Instead of beauty to direct it's light to, my skill goes cold, like the frozen world photography's absence has banished me to... 

My Needs & Your Rewards

I have done my research and this is a comprehensive list of the equipment/upgrades I am looking into:

  • Camera upgrade: T1i $430 via B&H 
  • OR just a better lens: EF 50mm f/1.8 II - $125  or EF 50mm f/1.4 USM - $400
  • Macbook Pro: $2000 
  • OR MacBook repaired (battery life is shot, display screen is damaged) : Estimated $600 flat rate repairs via Apple 
  • Vinyl Backdrops: Infinity 9x10 in Black, White, and Gray, $100 each via B&H
  • Tripod: Magnum DX-4330M Deluxe Photo Tripod/Monopod via B&H - $40
  • RadioPopper Jrx receiver: $100 (I have 1 but need another so I can sync multiple lights at various distances).

Added to that a small % to cover the fees for this site and anything I may need to cover the cost of incentives and you'll see that my math isn't too bad either. =)

My hope is that the incentives will provide you with a small token of my gratitude, a piece of my work (a.k.a. my heart) to remind you of the good people can do when we support one another, and at the very least I hope it makes you SMILE. =D 

I have several projects in the works, some of which you could participate in depending on the incentive/reward you select! 

  • The Local Locks Project - Documenting individuals with dreadlocks in my area, aimed at shattering the negative stigma surrounding dreadlocks and showing the variety and beauty of locks. 
  • The Twins Project - A fascination I share with my favorite photographer, Joyce Tenneson. Two individuals, each a half of one whole. There's magic there...
  • The Redhead Project - I have a particular fascination with redheads and I am anxious to collect faces of all the beautiful, exotic redheads out there! 
  • The Dancer Project - Another passion of mine, dancing creates such powerful shapes and projects such emotion. I know so many beautiful, talented dancers that I would love to photograph and show the world! 
  • The Tattoo Project - An ongoing project that has spanned nearly 7 years now. Tattoos are beautiful and personal; unique to the individual whose skin they adorn. I would love the opportunity to fully commit to this project and allow people to tell their stories and proudly display their work. 

Finding My Happy Place 

It's not easy for me to ask for help, especially in financial matters. I am learning that my skill is a gift and the inability to use that skill to help others is really starting to wear on me. I have so many projects and collaborations in queue, you are helping bring these to life. Your donation not only benefits me, but those I'll have the honor of photographing, involving in my projects and helping along in their endeavors.

I have had countless conversations with women that tell me how much being photographed gives them confidence. I love the opportunity to approach someone and help them see their own beauty. Most of the people I have photographed to date are friends who have indulged me and I would like to have a more professional set-up so that I can be confident in asking anyone to stand for me. 

The reality of the struggle...

I may not reach my goal. I understand that any donation gets me closer to my dream set-up and aids in improving the quality of work that I can provide. I have done pretty well thus far with pretty basic equipment and I have prioritized my needs based on what will get me back into the swing of it in the most timely manner. Any donation you make will be used with much gratitude and put towards the equipment needed for my most current project. 

You can be my hero! 

Money is only one of the ways in which you can back my campaign. If you support my struggle to take my work to the next level, please share this campaign via the provided links on this page and help me find more supporters! 

If you are local to me, please consider telling anyone who may be interested in supporting my campaign about my work and what I am trying to accomplish. 

Like my page on FaceBook and enjoy what I have created! 
My Facebook Page
story_txt:
I just want to photograph the things I love and share those images with the world. It's pretty simple really...

I struggled into my adult years to find My Thing. I fell in love with photography at the ripe old age of 21 and quickly learned that portrait photography was my happy place. It combines two of my favorite things, beautiful faces and beautiful lighting. A good portrait captures the subjects personality, it shows the best side of them and I became addicted to faces!  I do believe that a photo can steal your soul, or at least borrow it for a moment. A photo captures you in a light, in a mood, in a moment that will never exist in that exact equation again. 

Over the years, life has taken it's toll... I've moved so many times in the past 3 years that my equipment is damaged and a bit of an embarrassment. :/ My cat did something to my computer screen which has screwed up the display and so any post-processing has to be done on my boyfriends PC (and I am a MAC user at heart, iLove Apple!). The photograph I have used for this campaign was the last major photo shoot I did, 2 summers ago. That's how long it's been!!! Ouch!  I am anxious to start creating again using beautiful and fascinating faces, to play with light and textures, to show the world the view through my eyes. You could help me make magic again! And what's life without a little magic?! 

I miss capturing beautiful faces like the sun misses the flower in the depths of winter. Instead of beauty to direct it's light to, my skill goes cold, like the frozen world photography's absence has banished me to... My Needs & Your Rewards

I have done my research and this is a comprehensive list of the equipment/upgrades I am looking into:


Camera upgrade: T1i $430 via B&H 


OR just a better lens: EF 50mm f/1.8 II - $125  or EF 50mm f/1.4 USM - $400


Macbook Pro: $2000 


OR MacBook repaired (battery life is shot, display screen is damaged) : Estimated $600 flat rate repairs via Apple 


Vinyl Backdrops: Infinity 9x10 in Black, White, and Gray, $100 each via B&H


Tripod: Magnum DX-4330M Deluxe Photo Tripod/Monopod via B&H - $40


RadioPopper Jrx receiver: $100 (I have 1 but need another so I can sync multiple lights at various distances).


Added to that a small % to cover the fees for this site and anything I may need to cover the cost of incentives and you'll see that my math isn't too bad either. =)

story:
Hi my Name is Joel and with your Help we Hope to Ship my £200 car to Halifax, NS and drive to Tofino, with my Mum Julia and my 10 year Old Sister Courtney Visiting all Ten Provinces in the Process and driving over 8500km. 

We will have Blog Updating you of the progress of the Trip with Videos & Pictues.

At the end of the Trip we release Digital PhotoBook, If enough there is enough interest  shown physical photo book maybe released.

We are also doing Unquie postcards, You will be able to decide on a location on the Route, for example Niagara falls or Vancouver. Only you will receive that particular postcard. 

The Route.

Here is a outline of the route starting in St Johns, NL and ending In Tofino BC,

The route will change according to weather conditions as well as requests for postcards.



We are Aiming for 30 - 50 days on this trip, The more we raise longer can spend on it.

The Car

 

Cireton Saxo is the car we will be using for this trip. Built in france between 1996 - 2003. Never released in North America and Super small. 

The Saxo we will be using Is 1.1 Desire RHD version first registered in 2000, with 66,000Miles on the clock and purchased for £200 in 2014. 

For those of you that Pay £80 to have your name on the Car that will on one of the side panels. 

If you spend £1000 for company  you can cover door panel or the hood or back of the car.

Where your Money is Going.

The Cost of Shipping the Car from Southampton to Halifax is £900.

The maintenance costs and making sure the car can make it. 

The Headlamps and Tires will need replacing to make it safe to drive in Canada,

The Cost of Gas, Hotels to be able to make this trip.

The Cost  and time it takes to take and write and print the postcards. 

If we don't reach our goal we still aim to complete this trip though, Many places will be have to  skipped over and our time on the road will  a lot shorter.


Lastly 

If you got Questions or Ideas for Perks for feel free to Let me Know,

Thanks you to anyone that decided to Help and with this your help we can make this journey a success.

story:
What are you supporting:  

We are raising funds to run the training  phase of this project which helps people who have experienced homelessness to create a new life direction. We provide free workshops in transferable skills such as sales, public speaking and communications. This enables the participants to build their confidence and make some income selling the calendars and greeting cards that feature the winning photographs taken by the project participants.

 

MYTORONTO's goal is to provide people who are affected by homelessness with:  

  • Training in sales, communications and presentation skills 
  • Enhance confidence to connect with the public and workforce 
  • Opportunity to earn supplemental income 
  • Empowerment through art and self-expression 
  • A voice to share their stories in an effort to combat the stigma surrounding homelessness 
     

We Need Your Help: 

This year we are looking to expand the program’s training phase that supports people who have experienced homelessness to gain transferable skills and generate some income. We need to raise $7,500 to provide workshops in sales training, communications and presentation skills. These workshops will empower the participants to create a new life direction by boosting their confidence to re-enter the workforce. 

   

Funds will be used to:  

  • Deliver workshops in transferrable skills   
  • Create opportunities for participants to earn their own income 
  • Support the production of the MYTORONTO calendar and greeting cards 
  • Cover transportation costs for participants 
  • Provide outreach support and mentorship for participants 
  • Provide nutritious food at the workshops for people with lived experience of homelessness and poverty  

 

The Impact:  

Last year, MYTORONTO distributed over $4,000 in cash prizes to 40 photography contest winners and after attending some vendor training workshops, our participants earned over $14,000 by selling 1,700 calendars. This year we would like to increase the amount our participants earn by providing quality training and workshops, creating new MYTORONTO products and sourcing out more warm and busy venues where the participants can sell. We need your help in raising funds to enable this program to be a success.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help:  

Here are other ways you can help:  

  1. Share this campaign with your network through social media and word of mouth! Tell everyone that you are passionate about creating opportunities for people to move beyond homelessness, let them know about this project and  ask them to donate! 
  2. Fundraising can be done in different ways. Why get another expensive gift card that remains unused? Think about asking people to give a donation to MYTORONTO in your name instead!

 

The Year in a Glance:  

Creative Workshops - March 28th – May 2nd, 2018: 6 creative workshops were held at the 519 community centre to get our participants' creative juices flowing in preparation for the upcoming MYTORONTO Photography Contest. Topics included: Photography, Writing, Improvisation, Public Speaking and Media Skills.  

Camera Distribution Day – May 10th, 2018: Over 111 FujiFilm single-use cameras were handed out to people affected by homelessness at the Ryerson School of Image Arts. This year participants were asked to photograph what strength means to them in the City of Toronto.  

Camera Drop Off Day – May 15th, 2018: The photographers were given just 5 days to photograph Toronto through the lens of strength and 93 cameras were returned to be entered into the MYTORONTO Photography Contest.   

Jury Day – June 6th, 2018: Over 2600 photos were processed and printed for our panel of judges to select the top 40 photos for the MYTORONTO Exhibit.  

Public Vote – June 11th – 18th, 2018: Toronto also took part through our public vote and helped us determined one of the MYTORONTO Calendar Winners and People's Choice winner with over 1000 votes.  

MYTORONTO EXHIBIT AND VENDOR TRAINING PROGRAM LAUNCH – PRESENT: Our 13 calendar winners have been selected and we need your help to support the MYTORONTO Vendor Training program.  The program will enable participants with lived experience to sell MYTORONTO products for supplemental income, as well as gain sales, presentation and communication skills. This is where we need your support. Please see information provided above.  

 

About Ve'ahavta and the MYTORONTO Initiative: 

MYTORONTO is inspired by MYLONDON in London, England. MYLONDON started in 2013, one of the several art-related projects run by Café Art, including displaying art by people affected by homelessness in cafes and at pop-up exhibitions. Other projects Café Art run include the annual homeless art market and corporate art rental scheme.  

MYTORONTO was initially brought to Ve'ahavta and The Toronto Alliance to End Homelessness by an enthusiastic Ve'ahavta volunteer. The program was a huge success last year and Ve'ahavta is excited to be presenting and growing this initiative to offer skills and opportunities for income to people who are affected by homelessness.  

Ve’ahavta is a Jewish humanitarian organization dedicated to promoting positive change in the lives of people of all faiths and backgrounds who have been marginalized by poverty and hardship. Ve’ahavta mobilizes volunteers in meaningful, hands-on experiences to fulfill our collective responsibility to care for our neighbour. 

Ve’ahavta delivers programs that break down barriers, restore human dignity, foster capacity-building, and empower marginalized individuals to break the cycle of poverty. 

 

COME CHECK OUT THE MYTORONTO EXHIBIT FROM OCT. 11th – OCT 19th  at ARTSCAPE YOUNGPLACE.

story:
Juan is selling his photos!

Juan and I are selling some of his beautiful photography in hopes to get the funds needed to get him to Phoenix in Feb2013. Please check out the video which features the prints that we are selling and then visit the gallery link where you can see each individual print. We also are offering prints from Dan's wedding (a photo that was taken of you or the couple), and portrait packages. 

Please visit the gallery to see each individual photo!

The photos will be delivered around the end of Decemeber/new year.

To contact me about a specific photo or to see if we have one of you that you like, please email us at meghanlstone@gmail.com

Thanks!

story:
Quest for the... Calendar?

In October of this year, four men will be travelling across the Atlantic Ocean to start a trek that will take then 500 miles in four gruelling weeks of walking and camping using only Medieval gear - right down to costume, heavy canvas tents, and no lighter to start the campfire at night.

We are the Wayfarers, and this is our Quest for the Cure. We are doing this out of our own pocket in order to raise $100,000 for worldwide cancer research and support, and when we approached some of the fine ladies of Suicide Girls to help us out they jumped on board without hesitation.

In our Twelve Months of Magic calendar you'll see twelve of the top alternative models from around the world - from fan-favourite Suicide Girl Kemper to newcomers like Gallows and Artemis - taking their love of fantasy to new heights and helping us out by posing as pin-ups and having fun for a great cause.

Proceeds for the calendar - once funded - will be donated to the Association for International Cancer Research (or "AICR"), a charity based on St Andrews, Scotland.

The Money Thing

With donated time and photography, we don't need that much money to get these calendars off the ground. The $2000 in donations will be broken down like so, with all numbers being fairly rough:

//$200 for fees from IndieGoGo and PayPal.
//$650 for shipping costs for 100 calendars. This is to make absolutely sure we don't have to pay out of pocket for these calendars to find their way to your door! We will be sending calendars to Americans from New York State to save cross-border shipping costs.
//$1250 for one thousand calendars to be printed, including taxes. It only takes five days, so once we're funded and all the photos are in from our (amazing!) models, your calendars will be en route - nice and simple.

Excess money will be donated directly to AICR - absolutely none of the money will be considered "profit" or "play money." None of this money will go to help fund our trip or any other fundraising endeavour; once the calendars and shipping have been paid for, every other cent goes to AICR.

The Impact

We've run a number of fundraising campaigns for the Quest for the Cure in the last ten months, and have raised a decent chunk of our goal - almost $13,000 to three charities at the beginning of June. These calendars could raise over $10,000 by themselves if they are successfully sold out.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to buy a calendar? Don't want this particular piece of art hanging in your office, but still want to help out? There are lots of ways for you to do that:

  • Of course, please consider donating whatever you can directly to the charities in question through our donations page. Every dollar counts.
  • Visit our website and tell your friends about it!
  • "Like" us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter - the more we spread our signal, the better.
  • Check out the share tools that Indiegogo has set up to make as easy as humanly possible - Facebook, Twitter, etc. all at the click of a mouse.

story:
What We Want to Make

Hello, everyone! 
One more time we want to introduce you to a photo medium straight from the past. If you know the history of photography, you know that before film, dry photographic glass plates were the primary photo medium. You probably saw those pictures that were printed in the turn of the XIX century - with the magic effect of closeness and very natural feel even on simple objects.

So we, Galaxy Photography, the devotees of analog photography paraphernalia as we are, would like to have them in our collection as well. And since they are not commercially available, we decided to produce them ourselves through Kickstarter with your help.

Also: You'll need to use Dry Plates Holders - check out our current campaigns for Dry Plates Holders for large format cameras! 

4x5" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)

5x7" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)

8x10" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)

A Unique  Medium

What is so unique about the dry photographic plates?

Large format ensures a very wide tonal range of prints and fantastic resolution. The images taken from glass plate negative demonstrate a very smooth transition from shadows to lights and the highlights because the glass helps diffuse the light, providing the whole tonal shift. This creates a certain depth, and the image looks very realistic, smooth, clear, almost three-dimensional.

Second, we are making orthochromatic plates, meaning that they are not sensitive to red light. This characteristic makes the plates perfect for portraits because the emulsion allows concealing the blemishes on the faces, making the skin in the pictures smooth and even. In addition, these plates can be processed in the dark red light. This is a big advantage for plates as they need to be carefully loaded in the holders, and some kind of light is a great aid in that.

Also, glass has the quality of unsurpassed transparency, and therefore, reflects the details on paper much better, yielding crispy clear images.

Glass plates are more dimensionally stable, and the image will keep the proportion intact and reflect the object of the photo shoot the way it is. Unlike film, the glass won’t bend or distort, and the images will stay flawless.

And lastly, with plates, it is much easier to contact print onto photo papers as the weight of the glass presses the paper and the image is distributed evenly on the surface of the paper.

Costs and expenses.

WE ARE ABSOLUTELY STUNNED BY THE RESULTS OUR TEST GLASSES WERE ABLE TO PRODUCE. IT IS UNMATCHED EMULSION AND FANTASTIC MEDIUM! WE WANT EVERY PROFESSIONAL OR PHOTOGRAPHY LOVER TO BE ABLE TO TRY, EXPLORE AND ENJOY IT!

However, at this moment we are forced to set pledges costs way higher than we want due to several reasons:

 

First. The materials for glass production are quite expensive. Particularly the glass itself. We can’t use the regular windows glass from a local home improvement store. Although usual glass looks flat enough, only lab-grade glass meets photographic standards – flatness, thickness, etc. Of course, this type of glass costs more.

Second. Only few production facilities in the world can coat glass with required size, precision and quality. And they charge top dollar for outside orders.

Third. The volume of production significantly contributes to added expenses. Only orders for hundreds of thousands of dollars can bring the price down. We can’t project such support at the start, and therefore, we are forced to accept higher prices from facilities.

Forth. R&D for the recreation of materials from XIXth and XXth centuries materials is not an easy task. In fact, it’s a very costly task. Very few people in the world can be called real professionals in a very specific type of emulsion-making and photographic glass coating and we had to hire unique specialists to ensure the success of the project.

SHIPPING COSTS

As you can imagine, the glass itself is very heavy, especially the large formats in large quantities. Even local shipping can be expensive. 

For all your shipping-related concerns, please contact us here or through our website.

Some pledges are not listed at this time due to the fact that shipping cost may vary significantly. If you like to make a pledge which is specified in our Guide but currently is not listed among pledges, please contact us and we will accommodate your needs.

US & Canada.
The prices for delivery that we have listed now are based on USPS and Fedex Ground delivery (whichever is cheaper). Some of the pledges are not qualified for regular ground shipping due to the heavy weight but only for Freight shipments. We were able to preliminary negotiate a little bit better rates with West Coast and East Coast local courier companies but only if we can provide certain volume. If this, in fact, will be the case, all supporters will get credit with Galaxy for the applicable amount.

Europe/EU.
We work hard to start as soon as possible our European Distribution Center in the Czech Republic which should significantly bring down delivery prices in Europe. We expect this to happen in next few short months, but we don’t know exactly the amount which we’ll be able to shave off the cost of deliveries. We promise that we calculate savings individually and apply towards the every supporters’ credit with Galaxy for the applicable amount.

Asia.
During last few weeks we had several requests from distributors in several countries in Asia. Some of them really give us hope that our first LTC shipment to Asia will be on its way soon, and this will establish our regular trading and delivery root. Of course, this will generate savings in shipping cost, and all savings will be applied to every supporters’ credit with Galaxy for the applicable amount.

Australia. 
We had some talks with distributors in Australia. If we are able to send at least a pallet by sea, this can open a window for savings for local supporters too. All savings will be applied to every supporters’ credit with Galaxy for the applicable amount.

Rest of the World.
We are constantly looking for the way to deliver our products to all countries around the world as cheap and quick as possible. Please ask about your country if you have a specific question.

 

To Take A Picture

 

The specs of the plates we are going to make:

  • ISO 200
  • Color: Black & White
  • Sizes: 4x5, 5x7, 8x10, 11x14 (special pledge), 16x20 (special pledge)
  • Number of plates in pack: 10
  • Photo type: Negative

Before going over the process, we want the seasoned professionals to pardon us for such a detailed explanation.

To use the dry plates with your camera, you need to have special holders, which we also developed and would like to introduce as a separate project. We have made them specifically for our dry plates, so we guarantee a perfect fit. The holders are adjustable, meaning you will be able to use them with film as well! And the durable materials ensure the lack of light leakage.

The process of taking pictures with glass plates is as mesmerizing as a century ago. It consists of the following steps:

1. Place a dry plate contained in a plate holder into a slot in the camera.

2. Slide the cover from the plate holder to uncover the dry plate.

3. Set the exposure and take a picture.

4. Slide the cover on the plate holder back over the dry plate.

5. Remove the plate holder containing the exposed plate which was now ready for processing in a dark room.

Processing and Handling

To develop plates you will need to use a tray or a special tank, and if you have a special old frame for holding the glass, that will make the whole process easy.

But the whole process will be much more convenient with SP-445 Film System developed by Timothy Gilbert. Originally made for use with film, but now the fundraising campaign for 4x5'' glass dry plate in-system holder is going on Kickstarter. To get more details, follow this link: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1653453089... to this processing system you will be able to develop our dry plates safely and easily.

The best way to work with glass plates is contact printing. First, you need to develop the glass just like film. We will be manufacturing our proprietary developing chemistry kit for photo plates, but any commercial developer will work as well.

After you develop the glass plate, it will show the negative image of the composition that you shot. Now it’s ready for contact printing. All you need to do is lay the paper against the plate and expose it to light. After that, you will need to develop the paper.

Please, keep in mind that glass may be fragile if handled carelessly. The emulsion can be scratched off the glass surface easier than from a film, and for this reason, the developed plates should be kept in the envelopes packed individually or in special drawers.

The Story

Before the dry plates, photographers used wet plates for collodion process that became the medium for iconic photographs of the American Civil War. One major disadvantage of the plates was the fact that they had to be developed right on the spot, and the photographers were required to travel with a complete darkroom that was assembled for every exposure. The photographers of that time dreamed about the emulsion that was stable enough to be made ahead of time and keep long enough to get out on location for exposure and back to the darkroom. 

In 1871 the solution to this problem was found by a doctor who was also a photography enthusiast. Richard Leach Maddox discovered that gelatin allowed making dry plates with highly increased sensitivity. He decided not to patent his invention, but rather share it with the growing photo community. The word got around at viral speed and soon the photographers, both professional and amateur, were experimenting with the new emulsion recipe. Now dry plates were stable, with higher light sensitivity and could be stored for a long term.

In 1877, a 24-year old George Eastman started experimenting with gelatin dry plates recipe in his mother’s kitchen. By the next year he had not only perfected his technique, but invented and patented a machine for mass production of dry plates. With the demand for the dry plates soaring he left his old job as a bank clerk to open Eastman Dry-Plate Company, which is known today as Kodak Company.

Timeline

Stretch Goal

Our stretch goal is adding film of the same sizes as the plates and the same emulsion. They will be more affordable than plates and yield similar results - good for test shoots. They will require, however, a bit more efforts to work with, yet with a little experience there shouldn’t be any problems.

Who We Are

For those who don’t know about us: the main aim of our company is to preserve classic analog photography and its paraphernalia through various projects. We have successfully finished our first project last year and brought back to life direct positive photo paper for reversal project that was manufactured by Kodak about 70 years ago. Our second project was recreating photographer’s notebook that was among some of the most popular products for photographers in the last century. Another project is Galaxy Hyper Speed 120, a photo paper in the form of the film allowing you to shoot directly on paper and develop pictures on the spot. As you can see, our projects have a very wide span and we do not plan to stop on that.

Risks and challenges

 

Even though we are taking various precautions and adding more time to solve any possible issues, there still might be some situations that are out of our control.

1) Coordinating manufacturers. Several manufacturers will help us bring this project to life, and coordinating their activity might be challenging. There might be disruptions in either manufacturer’s process, which might result in delays. In addition, if some of the manufacturers provide faulty product for some reason, we will have to either reorder the batch or look for another manufacturer, which might be time-consuming. To prevent this, we try to work only with the manufacturers we already know and order samples beforehand to check the quality of the products.

2) Delays in shipping. This project is not our only business activity, and therefore, we might get distracted from shipment by other urgent tasks. Of course, we will clear our schedule for shipment as much as we can, but we have to leave some room for unpredictable events.

3) Juggling projects. We currently have another project launched at the same time, and we might get distracted by the issues connected with this project.

4) Force Majeure. During the past year we have experienced blackouts, floods in our office, earthquakes and foreign holidays that postponed our plans for about a month. Now we vigorously study national holidays in the countries of our manufacturers, looking for the office in a less flood-prone neighborhood and shopping for power generators.

What We Want to MakeHello, everyone! One more time we want to introduce you to a photo medium straight from the past. If you know the history of photography, you know that before film, dry photographic glass plates were the primary photo medium. You probably saw those pictures that were printed in the turn of the XIX century - with the magic effect of closeness and very natural feel even on simple objects.So we, Galaxy Photography, the devotees of analog photography paraphernalia as we are, would like to have them in our collection as well. And since they are not commercially available, we decided to produce them ourselves through Kickstarter with your help.Also: You'll need to use Dry Plates Holders - check out our current campaigns for Dry Plates Holders for large format cameras! 4x5" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)5x7" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)8x10" Holders (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/galaxy-unive...)A Unique  MediumWhat is so unique about the dry photographic plates?Large format ensures a very wide tonal range of prints and fantastic resolution. The images taken from glass plate negative demonstrate a very smooth transition from shadows to lights and the highlights because the glass helps diffuse the light, providing the whole tonal shift. This creates a certain depth, and the image looks very realistic, smooth, clear, almost three-dimensional.Second, we are making orthochromatic plates, meaning that they are not sensitive to red light. This characteristic makes the plates perfect for portraits because the emulsion allows concealing the blemishes on the faces, making the skin in the pictures smooth and even. In addition, these plates can be processed in the dark red light. This is a big advantage for plates as they need to be carefully loaded in the holders, and some kind of light is a great aid in that.Also, glass has the quality of unsurpassed transparency, and therefore, reflects the details on paper much better, yielding crispy clear images.Glass plates are more dimensionally stable, and the image will keep the proportion intact and reflect the object of the photo shoot the way it is. story:
*****With only a few days left in the campaign I decided to add another perk/incentive. I'm offering a 3-hour workshop, hike, or photo trip to the winner of a drawing. Anyone who orders 10 or more calendars is eligible for the drawing. The winner can give the workshop as a gift, if they choose. It must be conducted in or near the east valley and must be used at a mutually agreeable time before the end of Feb. 2017. Please email any questions to richardwebbtemples@gmail.com. ******

Here they are - the final images for the 2017 Arizona Temples Calendar


Introduction

My name is Richard Webb. I'm a native of Arizona.  I have a degree in Commercial Photography from Northern Arizona University and have been a freelance contributor and contract photographer for Arizona Highways magazine for many years.

I've learned that strong compositions, beautiful lighting, and dramatic skies make the best landscape images. The same elements also make for amazing Temple images. Creating powerful and inspiring images of LDS Temples has become a passion of mine.

Selling prints through Deseret Book and other LDS retail outlets has given me the chance to build an audience, connect with fans, and gain valuable feedback.

Over the years I received hundreds of requests for a calendar with my images. Last year I initiated a fundraiser just like this one and produced a 2016 calendar of Arizona's five LDS Temples.

The response was overwhelmingly positive and I received many more requests to continue producing calendars.

Objective

My goal now is to again produce a 14-month calendar featuring the five LDS Temples in Arizona. The calendar will actually have 16 Temple images, including the cover and an image on the year-at-a-glance page. It will make a great Christmas gift.

The purpose of this campaign is to fund the production and distribution of the calendar.  By backing this project you can receive one or more copies of the calendar for yourself, or to give as gifts.

Each page of the calendar will be 8 1/2" x 11", but the actual Temple images will be 8" x 10" in size. Past month's images can be removed from the calendar and put it in a frame, if you choose. This can be an economical way to display Temple images throughout your home.

Capturing the images and producing a quality calendar is expensive. There are significant upfront costs for equipment, travel, and the setup and actual printing. I've put in a lot of effort, this last year especially, to create amazing images for the calendar.  

My goal for this campaign is to raise enough funds to set up and print the calendar; pay for materials, postage, and labor; and pay all associated (Indiegogo, PayPal, credit card) fees and applicable taxes. 

I hope that you'll continue to check in on the campaign and keep sharing with those who might be interested.

Your Contribution

Your contribution, or backing, to this campaign is crucial. The more calendars I can print and the more successful this campaign is, the more likely I will be to continue to do this in the future.

In turn, this campaign lets you buy calendars (especially in quantities) at a discount. I'm not charging sales tax (I still pay the tax) and I'm offering even bigger savings for early supporters. Check the perks to the right for more details.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.

Please get the word out and let people know about this campaign. Share it on social media, email, and tell your friends and family. Also, use the Indiegogo share tools. Thanks for your help!

story:
Meet the best hand strap on the planet for all flagship brands of mirrorless and lightweight DSLR cameras - the SpiderLight Hand Strap.

Here’s an interesting problem: Our cameras are getting smaller, but our hands aren’t. Figuring out how to best hold your camera has become a challenge for anyone shooting for more than a few minutes at a time. Neck straps are cumbersome and clumsy no matter how you use them, and other hand straps are more trouble than they are worth.

The SpiderLight Hand Strap is an intelligent solution for the challenges posed by carrying today’s smaller cameras. It’s unique shape and ingenious construction make it the first of it’s kind. From the way that it feels in your hand, to the way that it makes you feel when you shoot with it... all the details have been designed make your experience empowering. Now you can take your camera anywhere, from the trail - to the street - to the studio, with a confident, secure, and comfortable grip.


  • get your hand in-and-out easily and quickly.
  • snug, comfortable fit for any hand size.
  • unique shape puts your hand in a perfect shooting position.
  • great support and stability when shooting hand-held video.
  • easy access to your camera controls.
  • works with any tripod.
  • super quick to get on and off your camera.
  • nice and sturdy. (not flimsy like other straps.)
  • includes adapters for compatibility with all leading mirrorless cameras.
  • did we mention that it feels great and looks beautiful?

 

Wait, didn't you guys already make a hand strap?

Yes, you’re thinking of our SpiderPro Hand Strap which was specifically designed for larger, heavier professional DSLR cameras. Our new SpiderLight Hand Strap brings all of the great features of our pro hand strap to the world of mirrorless and other smaller lightweight cameras.

Why do I need a hand strap?

With the support of a hand strap for your mirrorless camera, you have the freedom to comfortably carry your camera, ready to shoot, for long periods of time. That’s great for hiking a trail, taking a photo walk in the city, and shooting from the sidelines at your kid’s soccer game, band concert, or dance recital. It means you can carry your camera securely without a tangling, dangling, cumbersome neck strap. It means you can run fast with your camera, and stop and shoot in a split second. It’s fast, convenient, comfortable and secure.

What’s wrong with existing hand straps?

No one’s really ever loved their hand strap… that is, until now. Other hand straps are flimsy and hard to get your hand in and out of, they’re not comfortable for long periods of time, and they don’t truly support your hand. They also occupy your camera's tripod slot and need to be removed when using a tripod. The SpiderLight Hand Strap solves all those problems with its revolutionary design and ergonomics.

What's special about this hand strap?

Our new SpiderLight Hand Strap is specifically designed for smaller camera bodies like Fuji X-T1, SONY a7’s/7II’s, Olympus OMD to name a few. As good as they are, these cameras DO NOT have enough grip for your hand to hold comfortably for more than a few minutes - until now!

This is the first hand strap designed specifically for mirrorless and small DSLRs.

Our hand strap adapts to smaller/mirrorless camera bodies with a genius solution never conceived before – “smart” adapters that allow your hand to comfortably hold and securely handle your camera.

No more slippery hands, no more fear of dropping your cameras. It is the freedom of taking pictures everywhere, on the go.

How does it attach to my camera?

There are a few easy ways to attach our hand strap to your camera: use your tripod's quick-release plate (we're compatible with all brands), or use a Spider Plate (the thin profile at the end of the hand strap fits right between your plate and your camera body), or simply use the hardware included with our hand strap.

Will there be colors?

Oh yes. We’re including the option for a nice color trim. Available trim colors will be: Red, Copper, Deep Blue, Light Blue, Lilac, and standard Black.

What's it made of?

The outside is crafted from a proprietary nylon-based material that is extremely strong and flexible, allowing it to “remember” the shape of your hand. The inside is lined with a soft quality foam, covered with a velvet skin, making the hand strap super-comfortable and breathable. We wish you could touch it now, you wouldn't want to take your hand out.

An exciting addition for our Black Widow Holster, the backpack adapter allows you to holster your camera on any cushioned vertical strap backpack or messenger bag strap. A quick snap-in connection securely fastens our Black Widow Holster to your bag's strap with an ergonomic shape designed to work with the body's natural contours.


Some people think we're a big operation, but it's really just a few of us here at Spider HQ working to engineer, test, assemble, and ship out our products to all kinds of photographers around the world.

“I founded Spider based on my need as a professional photographer for a more ergonomic experience when out shooting long assignments. And I will continue to develop products that intelligently solve problems for all photographers, improving our workflows and shooting experience. Our new hand strap is very thoughtfully designed, and we put a lot of effort into making it compatible, comfortable, and secure.” 

— Shai Eynav, Founder & CEO, Spider Holster

We are particularly proud of the design innovation that went into our new light hand strap. Like our other products, and true to the Spider ethos, the SpiderLight Hand Strap is an intelligent solution to a common problem faced by everyday photographers.

Frequently Asked Questions

Will this strap work with the smaller Olympus OMD cameras?

It will work with your OMD by using the smart adapters that come with the strap.

What about the Fuji XT-1 and other mirrorless cameras where the shutter trigger is on top of the camera body?

No problem, our smart adapters ensure your hand is always in the proper shooting position for all flagship mirrorless and small DSLR cameras. See the photo below.

What is the projected production schedule/timeline once the campaign has been completed?

We will be shipping August 2016!

Will the hand strap work with a Nikon D7100 DSLR?

Your camera would probably fair better with the SpiderPro Hand Strap (http://spiderholster.com/handstrap).

I own a Canon 5D and use it with 24-105 f/4 regularly. I also own a Nikon 7200 and use it regularly with Nikon's 18-300 lens. Is this new SpiderLight hand strap intended for cameras of this size, or are they too big/heavy?

The SpiderLight Hand Strap was designed primarily for smaller mirrorless cameras. Larger cameras with heavier lenses should use our http://spiderholster.com/handstrap.

Does this new hand strap work with the battery grip on a Sony A7RII?

Yes, absolutely!

Will the rain cover be sold separately? If so, about what price? What about the other new items?

When our campaign ends, we'll be selling all individual products through our website, http://spiderholster.com. The rain cover will retail there for $25.

As the NEX-7 is now an older camera, will you have adapters for it?

Our smart adapters will work with the NEX 7.

Can the spider web be used by itself or does it have to be used in conjunction with the holster?

It can be used by itself, although it is not designed to be a carrying strap. It is a safety strap meant for added security and peace of mind.

Will this strap work with a Nikon D3300, or would the Spider Pro be more suited to that?

The Nikon D3300 is a good fit for the SpiderLight Hand Strap.

Risks and Challenges

The SpiderLight Hand Strap has been designed, tested, refined, and is now ready for production. We are confident that your support will allow us to get our new hand strap into production and into your hands this Summer.
story_txt:
Meet the best hand strap on the planet for all flagship brands of mirrorless and lightweight DSLR cameras - the SpiderLight Hand Strap.Here’s an interesting problem: Our cameras are getting smaller, but our hands aren’t. Figuring out how to best hold your camera has become a challenge for anyone shooting for more than a few minutes at a time. Neck straps are cumbersome and clumsy no matter how you use them, and other hand straps are more trouble than they are worth.The SpiderLight Hand Strap is an intelligent solution for the challenges posed by carrying today’s smaller cameras. It’s unique shape and ingenious construction make it the first of it’s kind. From the way that it feels in your hand, to the way that it makes you feel when you shoot with it... all the details have been designed make your experience empowering. Now you can take your camera anywhere, from the trail - to the street - to the studio, with a confident, secure, and comfortable grip.
get your hand in-and-out easily and quickly.
snug, comfortable fit for any hand size.
unique shape puts your hand in a perfect shooting position.
great support and stability when shooting hand-held video.
easy access to your camera controls.
works with any tripod.
super quick to get on and off your camera.
nice and sturdy. (not flimsy like other straps.)
includes adapters for compatibility with all leading mirrorless cameras.
did we mention that it feels great and looks beautiful?

 

Wait, didn't you guys already make a hand strap?Yes, you’re thinking of our SpiderPro Hand Strap which was specifically designed for larger, heavier professional DSLR cameras. Our new SpiderLight Hand Strap brings all of the great features of our pro hand strap to the world of mirrorless and other smaller lightweight cameras.Why do I need a hand strap?With the support of a hand strap for your mirrorless camera, you have the freedom to comfortably carry your camera, ready to shoot, for long periods of time. That’s great for hiking a trail, taking a photo walk in the city, and shooting from the sidelines at your kid’s soccer game, band concert, or dance recital. It means you can carry your camera securely without a tangling, dangling, cumbersome neck strap. It means you can run fast with your camera, and stop and shoot in a split second. It’s fast, convenient, comfortable and secure.
What’s wrong with existing hand straps?
No one’s really ever loved their hand strap… that is, until now. Other hand straps are flimsy and hard to get your hand in and out of, they’re not comfortable for long periods of time, and they don’t truly support your hand. They also occupy your camera's tripod slot and need to be removed when using a tripod. The SpiderLight Hand Strap solves all those problems with its revolutionary design and ergonomics.
What's special about this hand strap?
Our new SpiderLight Hand Strap is specifically designed for smaller camera bodies like Fuji X-T1, SONY a7’s/7II’s, Olympus OMD to name a few. As good as they are, these cameras DO NOT have enough grip for your hand to hold comfortably for more than a few minutes - until now!
This is the first hand strap designed specifically for mirrorless and small DSLRs.
Our hand strap adapts to smaller/mirrorless camera bodies with a genius solution never conceived before – “smart” adapters that allow your hand to comfortably hold and securely handle your camera.

No more slippery hands, no more fear of dropping your cameras. It is the freedom of taking pictures everywhere, on the go.

How does it attach to my camera?
There are a few easy ways to attach our hand strap to your camera: use your tripod's quick-release plate (we're compatible with all brands), or use a Spider Plate (the thin profile at the end of the hand strap fits right between your plate and your camera body), or simply use the hardware included with our hand strap.

Will there be colors?
Oh yes. We’re including the option for a nice color trim. Available trim colors will be: Red, Copper, Deep Blue, Light Blue, Lilac, and standard Black.

What's it made of?
The outside is crafted from a proprietary nylon-based material that is extremely strong and flexible, allowing it to “remember” the shape of your hand. The inside is lined with a soft quality foam, covered with a velvet skin, making the hand strap super-comfortable and breathable. We wish you could touch it now, you wouldn't want to take your hand out.



An exciting addition for our Black Widow Holster, the backpack adapter allows you to holster your camera on any cushioned vertical strap backpack or messenger bag strap. A quick snap-in connection securely fastens our Black Widow Holster to your bag's strap with an ergonomic shape designed to work with the body's natural contours.






Some people think we're a big operation, but it's really just a few of us here at Spider HQ working to engineer, test, assemble, and ship out our products to all kinds of photographers around the world.
“I founded Spider based on my need as a professional photographer for a more ergonomic experience when out shooting long assignments. And I will continue to develop products that intelligently solve problems for all photographers, improving our workflows and shooting experience. Our new hand strap is very thoughtfully designed, and we put a lot of effort into making it compatible, comfortable, and secure.” — Shai Eynav, Founder & CEO, Spider Holster
We are particularly proud of the design innovation that went into our new light hand strap. Like our other products, and true to the Spider ethos, the SpiderLight Hand Strap is an intelligent solution to a common problem faced by everyday photographers.





Frequently Asked Questions
Will this strap work with the smaller Olympus OMD cameras?
It will work with your OMD by using the smart adapters that come with the strap.
What about the Fuji XT-1 and other mirrorless cameras where the shutter trigger is on top of the camera body?
No problem, our smart adapters ensure your hand is always in the proper shooting position for all flagship mirrorless and small DSLR cameras. See the photo below.

What is the projected production schedule/timeline once the campaign has been completed?
We will be shipping August 2016!
Will the hand strap work with a Nikon D7100 DSLR?
Your camera would probably fair better with the SpiderPro Hand Strap (http://spiderholster.com/handstrap).
I own a Canon 5D and use it with 24-105 f/4 regularly. I also own a Nikon 7200 and use it regularly with Nikon's 18-300 lens. Is this new SpiderLight hand strap intended for cameras of this size, or are they too big/heavy?
The SpiderLight Hand Strap was designed primarily for smaller mirrorless cameras. Larger cameras with heavier lenses should use our http://spiderholster.com/handstrap.
Does this new hand strap work with the battery grip on a Sony A7RII?
Yes, absolutely!
Will the rain cover be sold separately? If so, about what price? What about the other new items?
When our campaign ends, we'll be selling all individual products through our website, http://spiderholster.com. The rain cover will retail there for $25.
As the NEX-7 is now an older camera, will you have adapters for it?
Our smart adapters will work with the NEX 7.
Can the spider web be used by itself or does it have to be used in conjunction with the holster?
It can be used by itself, although it is not designed to be a carrying strap. It is a safety strap meant for added security and peace of mind.
Will this strap work with a Nikon D3300, or would the Spider Pro be more suited to that?
The Nikon D3300 is a good fit for the SpiderLight Hand Strap.
Risks and Challenges
The SpiderLight Hand Strap has been designed, tested, refined, and is now ready for production. We are confident that your support will allow us to get our new hand strap into production and into your hands this Summer.

story:
Short Summary

The photo exhibition tells the story of unrequited love. Girl loves boy, boy doesn't love girl back.

Girl, in fact desires boy, though boy desires something else. The story is set in Haifa, Nazareth and beyond.

Your support will be crucial in helping us launch the photo exhibition on November 1 in Haifa and on November 27 in Nazareth!

Astral Desire utilizes the concept of the astral, which is a plane beyond the physical or energetic planes of life. In the astral state, a body is able to leave the physical and travel along the astral plane, able to experience the physical world, but as if floating, from the astral level. In the series, the girl leaves her body and astral travels from Nazareth to Haifa to be near the boy. The exhibition harnesses the concept of the astral to tell of a rather base human emotion, desire.

The photo series attempts to engage the audience on the affective economy of desire – how does desire circulate, how does it make individuals, subject and object of desire, how much of it is ‘authentic’ and how much culturally conditioned, how much is desire a search for recognition and the affirmation of one’s ego? 

Where: The exhibition will display in Haifa, Nazareth (Palestine 48) and in Jerusalem. There is a possibility it will show further afield, in Ramallah for example, though this depends on funding.

When: The exhibition will open in Haifa, with your support, on November 1 at the Abatjour Café (49 Hillel)! It will then show in Nazareth at Kitaabon on November 27. Subsequently, it will move to Jerusalem.

Why support?

When you donate, you are extending a hand to Palestinian, female artistic expression. This exhibition is important to us because it allows us to speak of our feelings, which as humanity, we do very little of. When it comes to Palestine, it seems we can only frame it within the context of war/resistance/conflict, and not about the human beings and the thickness of their emotions, everyday routines and relationships. This exhibition is about supporting art in Palestine and about supporting the telling of human stories in Palestine. For Palestinians and others.

Who are we?

We are a team of Palestinian artists/activists.

Katie Ramadan is a published poet and photographer and hosted a successful photo exhibition in Nazareth in February 2012, entitled 'In a Different Light'. The exhibition was a thirty-photo capture of Nazareth, Toronto, Mumbai and Paris, engaging the feelings embedded in community, loneliness and alienation. The primarily black and white exhibit was a call to courage in the recognition that experience with the unfamiliar is the path that leads us back home. 

Walid Mawid is a Palestinian curator and designer. He was the project designer and curator for the four year long 'water collection' project in Biella, Italy. He worked as costume designer for two acclaimed films on Palestine - Miral, directed by Oscar nominee, Julian Schnabel and Paradise Now, directed by Oscar nominee, the Palestinian Hany Abu-Asad. Walid and Katie worked together in the conceptualization, design and execution of the 2012 'In a Different Light' photo exhibit, which was opened by Director Hany Abu-Asad.

Sally Azzam Cook is the female model in this photo series and a social activist.

Nasser, Canadian, takes care of social media and production.

Our models, Sally and Walid (also curator and set designer of the exhibition)

What We Need & What You Get

The following is the breakdown of the budget items in US$:

Printing $500

Framing $335

Curator and Set Design Fee $560

Promotion and Social Media Costs $110

TOTAL US$ 1,500

[In addition, we have additional costs related to equipment, per diems, insurance and transport of art, but these are being secured from other sources]

For those very generous donors who've responded to our call to support independent art/photography and to support the same in Palestine, you will win the satisfaction of having done good. If that isn't enough, we'll be gifting you with postcards of a select photo from the exhibition, and for the very generous donors, unisex organic cotton t-shirts with a print of an exhibition photo!

In the event we don't hit our goal, every penny will be made to count in realizing the exhibition - though the extent of advertising, promotion, locations where they show may be scaled back. But give today so that we won't be forced to do that!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, no worries! You can also support in the following ways:

1) Visit the exhibition in Haifa between 1-21 November at Café Abatjour (49 Hillel)! Confirm your attendance:
https://www.facebook.com/events/695813660510360...

2) Live around Nazareth? Come to the exhibition during the three weeks it will show at Kitaabon, starting on 27 November.

3) Spread the word on social media to friends and family - facebook, twitter; use the hashtags #astraldesire #indiegogo

4) Follow us on tumblr: www.astraldesire.tumblr.com  and like us on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/astraldesireexhibition

Questions?

Contact Nasser at nasservictorrego [at] gmail.com and he'll be happy to respond :)

story:
Last month, we launched The Pet Concierge Global Education Center www.ThePetConcierge.com in the Bay Area.  Our mission is to connect pet lovers with renowned pet experts from around the world to offer cutting-edge educational content and access to effective pet treatments – helping pets throughout all stages of their lives. 

We created a community for pet lovers since we also recognized that one of the largest gaps in pet care today is the need of support services for those suffering through the loss of a pet.  We’ve recruited pet industry experts from a variety of fields and created a Pet Support Guide and Support and Healing Guide.
In the next few months, we will offer educational programming conducted by pet experts at the Education Center and via Google hang outs.

Our next goal is to create a Compassionate New Pet Photo Studio in the Bay Area


Creating a Pet Photography Studio for You and Your Pet

Having a photo shoot with your pet in the later/end stage of their life can be a truly rewarding way to bond with them and have a keepsake from some of your latter moments together.  The next phase of The Pet Passion project will be to partner with some of the Bay Area’s leading pet photographers to create an environment where people can bring their pets to capture such memories.  If your pet is aging, you may want to consider having a professional portrait of them to keep the memories lasting.

Fundraising Goal

  • We need $1,000 to create and build our pet photography studio.
  • Funds are for photographic equipment and studio set up.
  • We will recruit the best pet photographers in the Bay Area to take memorable photos of you and your pets!

The Impact

The Pet Concierge is partnering with the non-profit organization, The Pet & Wildlife Fund (www.PetandWildlifeFund.org). By making a contribution today, you will help us build a new studio for pet lovers in the Bay Area to capture the essence of their pets and help pets and wildlife in need. We will donate 15% of funds raised to benefit The Pet & Wildlife Fund toward the efforts of providing discounted vet care to pets and wild animals in need in the Bay Area.

How You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our new campaign.
  • Post a comment on our Indiegogo campaign page (insert live link here)
  • Share it with friends, business colleagues and family
  • Share our campaign on your social media pages


Here are some of our highlighted perks you get when you contribute...

When you contribute $10:

The Perk: Make sure your furry friend receives care he/she deserves with our “Top Questions to Ask Your Veterinarian” eBook. Choosing a veterinarian is one of the most important decisions you make as a pet owner, so make it count!

When you contribute $27:

The Perk: You’ll receive an e-book from award-winning vet, Dr. Gary Richter, about the proper nutrition for your pet. The phrase “you are what you eat” doesn’t just apply to us, it applies to our pets as well. Dr. Richter shares insights in his exclusive book.


When you contribute $45:

The Perk: Receive a set of 4 books published about pets and signed by award-winning 10-year-old, Abbey Richter, an Amazon Best-Selling Author. Abbey shares stories about four interesting pets. Each book is about a pet who has been adopted and found love; Lucky Leo, Stunning Stella; Everyone Loves Charlie Brown and Fabulous Frieda.


When you contribute $100:

The Perk: If your pet is sick, has low energy, in pain or has a wound that needs healing, you’ll receive a 30-minute Reiki Healing treatment from a Reiki Master and Happiness Coach. Reiki is a form of energy healing that helps to reduce stress, anxiety, physical and emotional pain for both humans and animals. This perk can be used for yourself or your furry friend!

When you contribute $147:

The Perk:  Pay homage to a pet you lost with a “My Pet Lives On” biodegradable urn that allows you to plant your pet’s ashes and/or a photo and let them “rebirth” in the form of a tree. Receive a Biodegradable urn.


When you contribute $997:

Award-winning Pet Photographer Lori A. Cheung, ThePetPhotographer.com, will photograph your pet(s) within 20 miles of San Francisco (or travel expenses covered by the contributor) at the studio, beach, park, or another inspiring location.  You'll receive three 8x10-inch fine art prints, matted and signed by Lori in archival 16x20-inch museum mats.

story:
On September 1st, 2007, I married the girl of my dreams. Jen was my best friend and I knew the minute I first saw her that she was the one. The following February, only five months after our wedding, Jennifer was diagnosed with breast cancer. In December of 2011, Jen passed. 

At times during Jen's treatment we realized that our family and friends did not understand how serious our life had become, and really, how could they?

Thankfully, Jennifer let me photograph our day to day life so we could let them in on it. 

The money raised through this campaign will allow me to share these photos with the world and produce a book that will accompany a traveling exhibition. The photographs, centering around Jennifer and her battle with breast cancer, tell a story of love, grace and courage in the face of a horrible disease. 

My goal is to bring awareness to the realities of a daily life with cancer and the importance of being there for someone who is fighting for his or her life. 

Since I will be publishing this book (hard copy and ebook) on my own it will be my responsibility to oversee all aspects of its production. In order to achieve the level of quality I desire I will assemble a team consisting of a photo editor, a designer, a PR/Marketing consultant and myself. Together we will work to produce a book and exhibition that will not only inform but also inspire.

My photographs are not just about cancer; they are about love and life, and never giving up. They are about embracing every second.

PRESS ABOUT THE BATTLE WE DIDN'T CHOOSE

CNN.com

USA Today

The Guardian - UK

Fox 8 Cleveland

WKYC NBC - Cleveland

WEWS ABC - Cleveland

Cleveland Plain Dealer

Around Noon NPR-Cleveland

One Wig Stand

Feature Shoot

RESPONSES TO OUR STORY

- "Wow. Powerful series of photos from @CNN. http://cnnphotos.blogs.cnn.com/2012/01/18/cancer-the-battle-we-didnt-choose/" - Lance Armstrong Via Twitter

 - "I look at the incredibly powerful photographs of Jen Merendino. This is what I look like. I think I am beautiful. I am hundreds of thousands strong across the globe.I have sisters in Australia, Dubai, United Kingdom, Singapore just to name a few.We are all beautiful. We are incredibly strong.Thank you Angelo for showing our faces through your beloved Jen." - Private

- "Seeing your story and photos made me look at my own diagnosis with breast cancer as a wake up to live!" - K.A.

- "Your posts about you and Jen always make me smile. It's obvious that you both are and were very much in love with each other and made every single day count." - A.L.

- "Your guys love & story is so inspiring." - J.L.P.

- "Each and everytime I get the blues and think life is not worth it I visit your site too. Jen is an inspiration, an angel that touches so many." - P.S.

AWARDS

2012 - Selected to attend the 25th annual Eddie Adams Workshop

2012 - Featured in the 2012 Communication Arts Photography Annual 

2012 - Featured in the 2012 Creative Review photo annual

2012 - Honorable Mention - The Art of Documentary/SDN

2011 - Recipient People’s Choice – Artist’s Wanted

EXHIBITIONS

11/2012 - Perugia Social Photo Festival, Perugia, Italy

10/2012 - Solo show, ADC Gallery, Cincinnati, OH

7/2012 - Solo Show, Convivium Gallery33, Cleveland, OH

7/2012 - Shoot4Change "4 Continents 4 Change", Soho, NY

5/2012 - NY Photo Festival, "The Art of Documentary", Brooklyn, NY

1/2012 - Solo show at The Lower East Side Girls Club, Manhattan, NY

11/2011 - Solo show, 78th St. Studios Monthly Art Walk, Cleveland, OH

PROJECT EXPENSES

 

Exhibition

Prints

8x10 @ $12ea - 20 prints = $240

13x19 @$36ea - 20 prints = $1440

24x36 @ $128ea - 10 prints = $1280

Total = $2,960

Framing

(10) 24x36 @ $225ea = $2,250

(20) 13x19 @ $125ea = $5,000 

(20) 8x10 @ $90ea = $1,800

Total = $9,050

 

Book

Design and production

Book designer - $10,000

Photo Editor - $3,000

ISBN# (Needed to list the book with The Library of Congress) - $350

Ink and paper (Working edit prints) $600

Total = $13,950

Promotion

Marketing/PR - $10,000 

Initial printing costs

13x11 Hardcover, 21-40 pages = $85.32

Volume orders

100-249 - 15% = $72.53

100 books = $7,253 + shipping

Book proofs - 5 13x11 proofs @ $85.32ea = $426.60 + shipping - roughly $500

Total = $8,000

 

Personal expenses

6 months living expenses (est. time to produce book & exhibition) @ $3,500 per ($3,000) =$18,000

Total = $61,690

 

FEES

Indiegogo - 3%= $1,858.80

Credit Card Processing - 4% = $2,467.60

Perks - $5,000

Total = $9,326.40

 

CAMPAIGN TOTAL = $71,286.40

 

PERKS

All book related perks (hard copy and eBook) will be delivered upon completion of the book. My goal for the release of this book is February of 2013, 5 years from when Jen was initially diagnosed. 

Prints for perks will be ordered at the end of the campaign. The prints will be shipped to me for signing and numbering and then sent out to recipients. Expect prints to arrive in January, 2013.

Thank you for your generosity.
story_txt:
On September 1st, 2007, I married the girl of my dreams. Jen was my best friend and I knew the minute I first saw her that she was the one. The following February, only five months after our wedding, Jennifer was diagnosed with breast cancer. In December of 2011, Jen passed. 
At times during Jen's treatment we realized that our family and friends did not understand how serious our life had become, and really, how could they?
Thankfully, Jennifer let me photograph our day to day life so we could let them in on it. 
The money raised through this campaign will allow me to share these photos with the world and produce a book that will accompany a traveling exhibition. The photographs, centering around Jennifer and her battle with breast cancer, tell a story of love, grace and courage in the face of a horrible disease. 
My goal is to bring awareness to the realities of a daily life with cancer and the importance of being there for someone who is fighting for his or her life. 
Since I will be publishing this book (hard copy and ebook) on my own it will be my responsibility to oversee all aspects of its production. In order to achieve the level of quality I desire I will assemble a team consisting of a photo editor, a designer, a PR/Marketing consultant and myself. Together we will work to produce a book and exhibition that will not only inform but also inspire.
My photographs are not just about cancer; they are about love and life, and never giving up. They are about embracing every second.
PRESS ABOUT THE BATTLE WE DIDN'T CHOOSE
CNN.com
USA Today
The Guardian - UK
Fox 8 Cleveland
WKYC NBC - Cleveland
WEWS ABC - Cleveland
Cleveland Plain Dealer
Around Noon NPR-Cleveland
One Wig Stand
Feature Shoot
RESPONSES TO OUR STORY
- "Wow. Powerful series of photos from @CNN. http://cnnphotos.blogs.cnn.com/2012/01/18/cancer-the-battle-we-didnt-choose/" - Lance Armstrong Via Twitter

 - "I look at the incredibly powerful photographs of Jen Merendino. This is what I look like. I think I am beautiful. I am hundreds of thousands strong across the globe.I have sisters in Australia, Dubai, United Kingdom, Singapore just to name a few.We are all beautiful. We are incredibly strong.Thank you Angelo for showing our faces through your beloved Jen." - Private

- "Seeing your story and photos made me look at my own diagnosis with breast cancer as a wake up to live!" - K.A.
- "Your posts about you and Jen always make me smile. It's obvious that you both are and were very much in love with each other and made every single day count." - A.L.
- "Your guys love & story is so inspiring." - J.L.P.
- "Each and everytime I get the blues and think life is not worth it I visit your site too. Jen is an inspiration, an angel that touches so many." - P.S.

story:
Short Summary

That’s me: 27 years old employed guy that spends all his free time studying, improving and shooting to make a dream come true, being a professional photographer.

If I try to remember when I fell in love with photography I suppose that the answer can be only when daddy used to shout me back because I was touching his Nikon, it was prohibited AND it could simply stop the time with a “click”, than day after day cent after cent I followed a passion, before with an analogical camera than with a mirrorless and finally thanks to a real friend I started handling  a semi-professional dslr Canon, the dream was taking his shapes. 

I started making small books to patient friends, than someone noticed my photos and asked me for some shots,  I was the proudest on earth, I was doing it, and all by myself! The step after has been made by some local clubs that asked me to take photos at their main events. And that’s when I started thinking that my dream could really come true. And the first photographic project was taking his shapes, a photographic book about forgotten and abandoned buildings, at first on the Maltese islands, than in the southern Europe, and perhaps who knows even more!

The hard part now is to buy new equipment, such as lights, bunkers, umbrellas AND a new camera.

I settled the fund raising campaign at 5000€ thinking of the new camera, a Canon 5D mk3, two umbrellas, two soft box, and of course the printing fees for the first copies of the book.

The idea is to start this new adventure, and of course YOUR help will be essential, I'm working hard to realize my project and I really think that whatever will happen, even if it will take more time, my dream will be realized, but of course with your help you will have at least a new book in your library.

I've always thought that the art of photography wasn't only made by  a “perfect click”, that can be done almost from everyone with modern technologies, but was having the capability of transmitting something to whoever looks at your work, and as a part of my project you will become my first audience, and the first people that I’d love to be impressed.

Other Ways You Can Help

I can understand if you really can’t help me physically raising my dream, but please share my project to your contacts, perhaps some of your friends or contacts can do it even for you!

So please remember to share my project through the indiegogo sharing tools

Thank you in advance!

Federico

Ragazzo di 27 anni che passa tutto il suo tempo libero studiando, migliorando e scattando foto per far diventare un sogno realtà: diventare un fotografo professionista.
Credo che questa frase mi dipinga perfettamente, se provo a ricordare il momento in cui scoccò la scintilla fra me e il mondo della fotografia, probabilmente la risposta la troverei pensando alle sgridate di mio papà quando andavo a toccacciare la sua Nikon, era un oggetto proibito e quindi di per se interessante e poi poteva fermare il mondo con un "click". Da quel momento giorno dopo giorno ho inseguito una passione prima con delle macchine analogiche, poi con una compatta digitale e finalmente grazie ad un caro amico ho avuto fra le mani la prima reflex digitale, il mio sogno prendeva lentamente forma.                            Ho iniziato a fare foto agli amici che, con infinita pazienza, mi hanno sempre sopportato e supportato fino a quando un giorno qualcuno ha iniziato a notare le mie foto e mi ha chiesto di fare degli scatti insieme. Il passo dopo è arrivato da solo, alcuni locali della zona mi hanno contattato per andare a fare foto nei loro eventi principali, e il mio sogno sembrava ogni giorno più a portata di mano, e più si avvicinava e è più il mio primo progetto fotografico vero prendeva forma: un libro fotografico sugli edifici storici abbandonati e ricchi di mistero, all'inizio sull'isola di Malta, poi in sud europa e poi chissà.La parte più difficile arriva ora, riuscire a far partire il progetto, acquistare le attrezzature di cui ho bisogno e iniziare a lavorare sodo.L'idea è di iniziare questa nuova avventura in ogni caso sia che la capagna vada a buon fine sia che invece non riesca ad arrivare alla somma pensata, e naturalmente il vostro aiuto sarà essenziale, sto lavorando sodo per realizzare il mio progetto e credo davvero che qualunque cosa accadrà, anche se ci vorrà più tempo, il mio sogno verrà realizzato, ma, naturalmente, con il vostro aiuto sarà tutto molto più semplice.Ho sempre pensato che l'arte della fotografia non sia solo arrivare a fare un "perfetto click", che può essere fatto quasi da tutti con le moderne tecnologie, ma che sia avere la capacità di trasmettere qualcosa a chi guarda il tuo lavoro, e come parte attiva del mio progetto diventerete il mio primo pubblico, e le prime persone che mi piacerebbe colpire.

story:
[The Brief]

In January 2013, I will be joining International Teams Uganda for a media missions trip. 

International Teams Uganda works, “with a vision to see lives and communities transformed by the power of God.  Their mission is to walk alongside the local church to reach out to the oppressed in specific roped-off communities in the Teso region and beyond; more specifically, it is to energize, equip and engage local Christians passionate about specific areas of ministry to grow deep roots in the Biblical worldview – centering on Jesus, the full expression of the Father’s love and value of human life – and, as a result, to bring hope, dignity and wholeness to the poor, slave and blind within their communities.” –Tim Sliedrecht, Team Leader, Uganda.

Uganda has faced drastic hardship and suffering for the past 40 years.  Through the power of God, change and transformation is happening.  I believe that each of us have been given gifts to greatly impact the world around us.  Over three weeks, through my gifts of photography and videography, I will be working alongside the local churches in Soroti, Obulle, Pampa, and Achelle. Capturing stories of hope and transformation, will help to educate, inspire, influence, liberate, edify, and encourage.

 

[The Need]

-Prayer Support.  Prayer works.  It overcomes, it heals, it moves, it engages, it makes the impossible possible.  Prayer is very much appreciated for:

-The country of Uganda: peace, food, forgiveness, freedom, receiving the                           fullness of Christ

-Team unity

        -Health

        -Equipment would not be lost/stolen/broken/fail

        -Divine creativity to tell stories well and with trust and integrity

        -Financial Support

-Financial Support.  My goal is to raise $5,000.  This will cover:

         -Transportation

         -Equipment rentals/purchases

         -Housing

         -Food

-Digital Cameras

-Have an old digital camera?  We would LOVE to have it!  Email me at bach.marianne@hotmail.com.

 

[The Impact]

Your donation WILL make a difference.

International Teams Uganda is fighting for the oppressed and the least of these.  Through the local church, they are seeing that everyone receives food, freedom, and forgiveness.  No one is invisible.  Tangibly, this looks like loving former child soldiers and helping them process their pasts and grab hold of their futures.  This also looks like visiting the widow’s home and helping a whole village benefit from clean water.  Farms are reaping crops and street children are being cared for. 

While in Uganda, I will be specifically working with Andrew Nicdoem, and Ryan Gilles (namingtheworld.org).  Together, we will capture the stories of beneficiaries and share how transformation has come through the love of God.  We intend to create media that will bring awareness to local communities on specific issues.  We also have an opportunity to do a photography club and educate on photo ethics and skills.

Thank you!

Please email me at bach.marianne@hotmail.com with any questions at all!

 

***If you would like to donate by check, email me and I can send you my address!
