story:
Round 4 of the periodic photo project.

The donor 'thank-you' photos from Round 3:

My name is Mark Wyatt. I've been photographing interesting and unfamous people on city streets since around 1980 (examples below). Over those 35 years my photographs have almost without exception never ventured outside my home - I have been my own audience and only critic, tacking new images to the walls of my workroom until it gets too crowded and then retiring a few to a file box to make room for the next.

For quite a while now however, I've had to listen to a nagging voice telling me that I haven't done enough, not nearly enough. And it's right. I've photographed as much as my job has left time for, but it's been sporadic and I know that I haven't done as much or as well as I should.

Since none of the photos have ever been exhibited or published or sold, I don't know if there's a place for them anywhere other than where they live today.  If not, I'll just keep doing what I've been doing.  But if the work can finance itself, then I can do more, do better, and hopefully create a significant body of work.

So I'm here at indiegogo because despite the need for funding, I want very much for the work itself to remain the primary goal if not the exclusive one as it has been for the past 35 years - and here is one place where an ambition can be financed with modest donations from strangers who have no agenda or connection to the goal other than that they see it as worthwhile.

If the examples below have piqued your curiosity, please go to mwwyatt.wordpress.com to view more, and if you find what you see there to be worthy, come back and make a $20 donation.  In thanks for your donation, I'll send you four 4x6 prints, signed and numbered.

Every image you see and every print you'll receive in the mail is uncropped and minimally processed - it is what the camera saw, the full frame printed archivally and adjusted only to get as close as possible to what I saw and was hoping to capture. The images are simple and pure - from my eye to the camera to the print to you with as little manipulation as possible along the way.

The proposal is equally simple. There is essentially one donation level - 20 dollars; and the only thank-you gift is the set of four prints. Every week or two (or three), I'll run a new campaign for 15 days with a new set of 4 thank-you prints.  And I'll keep doing that hopefully for a very long time. You can collect a new set each round or jump in and out as you please. My promise is to create more and deliver the results to you in a future round.  And together we'll watch and grow and see where this all goes.

There are also a few multiple-donation levels so that you can donate today for future rounds, if you want to make sure not to miss one. Donors to future rounds will be sent their thank-you gifts as each successive round ends.

These images do not intend to make a statement.  They are observations, simple snapshots of everyday people being everyday people.  There is no message hiding in a theme or revelation to be found by analyzing the context.  The subject is the phenomenon called the human condition, unburdened by any attempt to explain it. Each image is meant to feel familiar, even if you're looking at it for the first time, because an emotion captured in a stranger's expression is where we and the code that runs our family of man intersect.  To make that connection is the reason for these photographs. I hope that as you look them over, you'll see what I mean.

Enjoy. And thank you.

If you would like to be put on the mailing list to get pinged when I launch a new Round, of course the best way is to contribute one or more Jacksons. On the other hand, if you just want to be on the list, shoot me an email with something like 'Yes' or 'Subscribe' in the Subject field: mwyattfotograf@gmail.com.

Risks and challenges

There are two risks: 
1. This is Round 4 of a project whose end is not known, and since donors can donate today for future rounds and each print is uniquely numbered, it is possible that the first donor to a particular round will not necessarily receive the print with the '001' number. 
While there may be a perceived risk in donating now to future rounds, there is no more risk in donating to future rounds than there is in donating to the current round; by accepting your donation, I am promising to deliver the perks as described. 
2. Every set of prints will come to you as a surprise - which four images you will receive in thanks for your donation will only be revealed when you open the envelope. However, as there'll be a new campaign every week or two with a new set of four prints, I intend to include at least one of the older black-and-white images in each set until they run out. The images in a particular set will be unique to that campaign and none will be repeated. The purpose of the campaign, after all, is to enable the creation of new ones.


Round 2 Donor photos:

Round 1 Donor photos:

The proposal is equally simple. There is essentially one donation level - 20 dollars; and the only thank-you gift is the set of four prints. Every week or two (or three), I'll run a new campaign for 15 days with a new set of 4 thank-you prints.  And I'll keep doing that hopefully for a very long time. You can collect a new set each round or jump in and out as you please. My promise is to create more and deliver the results to you in a future round.  And together we'll watch and grow and see where this all goes.
There are also a few multiple-donation levels so that you can donate today for future rounds, if you want to make sure not to miss one. Donors to future rounds will be sent their thank-you gifts as each successive round ends.
These images do not intend to make a statement.  They are observations, simple snapshots of everyday people being everyday people.  There is no message hiding in a theme or revelation to be found by analyzing the context.  The subject is the phenomenon called the human condition, unburdened by any attempt to explain it. Each image is meant to feel familiar, even if you're looking at it for the first time, because an emotion captured in a stranger's expression is where we and the code that runs our family of man intersect.  To make that connection is the reason for these photographs. I hope that as you look them over, you'll see what I mean.
Enjoy. And thank you.








If you would like to be put on the mailing list to get pinged when I launch a new Round, of course the best way is to contribute one or more Jacksons. On the other hand, if you just want to be on the list, shoot me an email with something like 'Yes' or 'Subscribe' in the Subject field: mwyattfotograf@gmail.com.
Risks and challengesThere are two risks: 1. This is Round 4 of a project whose end is not known, and since donors can donate today for future rounds and each print is uniquely numbered, it is possible that the first donor to a particular round will not necessarily receive the print with the '001' number. While there may be a perceived risk in donating now to future rounds, there is no more risk in donating to future rounds than there is in donating to the current round; by accepting your donation, I am promising to deliver the perks as described. 2. Every set of prints will come to you as a surprise - which four images you will receive in thanks for your donation will only be revealed when you open the envelope. However, as there'll be a new campaign every week or two with a new set of four prints, I intend to include at least one of the older black-and-white images in each set until they run out. The images in a particular set will be unique to that campaign and none will be repeated. The purpose of the campaign, after all, is to enable the creation of new ones.Round 2 Donor photos:Round 1 Donor photos:

story:
OUR STORY

 

MUD Africa (Mobilizing + Uniting Development in Africa) is an NGO working to better the lives of Malawians as advocates of land and housing rights. (www.mudafrica.org) Malawi is one of the most rapidly urbanizing countries in the world at a rate of 6.3 percent per year. That is three times the global rate and nearly twice that of the African rate. Unfortunately, the economy lacks proportional growth measures necessary to address and reduce poverty levels, and epidemic becoming more visible in the increasing manifestation of informal settlements (slums). Mutually reinforcing conditions of these settlements include poor infrastructure, water and sanitation, substandard housing with insecure tenure and a lack of basic social services.

 

MUD Africa is an advocate for 'the Right to Adequate Housing' as recognized under the International Bill of Human Rights, using seven defining factors of 'adequacy' identified by the Committee of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights under the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR). Malawi is one of the 171 nations to adopt the Habitat Agenda II in 1996, making them responsible for ensuring this human right is upheld. Despite a general consensus by all nations of failure to induce social development through aid, MUD Africa is aware that international agencies have been successful in cooperating with grassroots projects in neighbouring African countries. The creation of grassroots movements has worked to raise considerable awareness of housing and land rights throughout poor communities. MUD Africa uses a bottom-up approach to slum redevelopment and upgrading, stressing the importance of community-based organization and involvement in shelter projects. 

 

As part of MUD Africa's engagement in shelter, we are first developing a three-month documentary series, which will begin in mid-April 2012 and conclude in mid-July 2012. Information on the ground will be collected and compiled; using photography, video, interviews and personal accounts which support a social mapping exercise; the theme being 'the Right to Adequate Housing'. The project is intended to stimulate global awareness while securing local plans of action. The seven defining components of 'adequate' stated by the Committee of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights include: legal security of tenure, availability of services, material, facilities and infrastructure, affordability, habitability, accessibility, location, and cultural adequacy. The photo/video documentary series will be done with a specific focus on all/most of the seven components of 'adequate' which highlights specific cases, all the while an in-depth investigation will be done to record and further analyse a broader spectrum of related information through questionnaires, debates/conferences, etc. within various communities.


THE IMPACT


Nearly every nation worldwide recognizes the basic human right to adequate housing. No citizen, regardless of age, economic status, gender, ethnicity or other criteria, should question his or her government's concern for his or her need for adequate housing. Article 2 of the United Nations Right to Adequate Housing Convention prohibits discrimination by governments against individuals involving their right to adequate housing.

The level of housing that constitutes adequate housing can be subjective. The term adequacy is defined and perceived very differently depending on social groups and cultures. Formal housing is almost exclusively a middle-class concern as it has been found low-income households give higher priority to other needs, once adequate basic shelter is obtained and basic services are provided, than to improve their housing conditions. This does not imply the low-income population does not want formal housing; rather, planners and developers should not presume the main concerns of different social groups and dismiss their priorities of allocating scarce resources. This is often unexplored and misunderstood in interventions proposed by the international community.

To create a measure of adequacy in various contexts, MUD Africa will work to establish a monitoring system that takes into account affordable health, environmental and building standards appropriate and applicable to local conditions. Information collected through on-going monitoring will help to assist international developers, such as architects, urban planners and so forth to establish the first-stages of housing and ensure project needs are met.

The project builds on a bottom-up, participatory model for later project development. This approach ensures the data collected and proposals optimized are as culturally sensitive and realistic as possible, furthering inclusiveness, empowerment and lasting commitment.

The documentary project will be made into a published book to share the findings and continue to raise funding for the next stages of the project, with an additional exhibition of the photos and recorded, edited video footage. Photography is not only documented 'evidence' but a tool to communicate across a host of barriers. Smaller photography editorials will be published on the MUD Africa website monthly along with a written 'diary' of the findings. 


The following areas will be addressed after this three-month documentary project:

1. Revision of housing policy to make it more inclusive of low-income households and disadvantaged individuals
2. Revision of housing policy to recognize new/alternative building technology and sustainable materials, enabling new mortgage options.
3. The sustainable, physical upgrade of existing low-income housing to address issues also related to health and livelihoods.
4. Community housing rights and educational outreach programmes

WHAT WE NEED


We are looking for 6,000 USD for this initial three month project. This will go towards the upgrade of equipment and software, transportation, exhibition costs such as printing and framing, campaign materials, renting a space to hold community meetings, communication (phone/internet), a translator, and related activities/ every day costs over the entire three month period.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP


Please help us to spread the word about MUD Africa and the campaign by posting this on Facebook, Twitter and other social media sites. The more people whom become aware of the cause, the more likely we are to raise the needed funds to get MUD off the ground and action into communities. If you can think of any other way to contribute, please write to us at info@mudafrica.org We thank you all very much (in advance) and appreciate all of your support and enthusiasm.

story:
The Désiré project

This is a project that I have been working on for several months. It began with my archiving older photographic images, filing them and generally organizing all the images I have taken over the past 20 years. As I was reviewing all of these photographs, it occurred to me that some of the images that I had previously decided not to use, either due to accidental camera shake or double exposure, had very strong compositional value to them. Coincidentally, at the same time that I was going through my old photographs, I had been researching historical Albumen printing process for possible use in printing my still life images. The still life photographs all include antique tin type portraits, and researching alternative and longstanding methods of printing seemed fitting.  Then an idea came to me.

I started by creating a digital negative a la’ Dan Burkholder, with whom I had the pleasure of working back in 1996. After creating the negative and outputting via Lightjet onto clear film, I sent the new experiment to a NYC lab that I knew still did alternative processes. 

I was very impressed with the result! In June of 2012 I finished my selection process, choosing the previously discarded images that now shine in this new series. I realized that due to the cost, technical complexity and size limitations that are part of the Albumen process, it may not be the best way to go, but I wanted to maintain the aesthetic of the Albumen printing process as they complemented the images superbly. I would like to publish this new series in a limited edition photographic book.

Why I need your help

The funds raised via Kickstarter will allow me to complete, print and publish a third book of photography based solely on these rediscovered images. 

This collection of the newly created Desire’ series will be produced as a limited edition, 26 page 8” x 10” hardcover photographic book printed on real archival quality photographic silver-halide paper.

story:
WHAT IS CODA?

‘Coda’ is a Solent University student showcase to highlight the best up and coming works of our generation. Portraying a wide variety of concepts, it allows you to engage with the final works of their Degree.

2nd-12th June ‘Coda’ @ PrintSpace http://www.theprintspace.co.uk
12th-19th June ‘Coda’ @ Southampton Solent University

The class of 2015 BA(HONS) Photography students at Southampton Solent University, are holding two Degree Shows. One located in Southampton, and the other at the London PrintSpace. As a group of intuitive and enthusiastic photographers, we are gathering the funds to hold our exhibition ‘Coda’ to the highest of standards to best portray ourselves as aspiring artists within the field of photography.

ONGOING PROJECTS  
 
There are 42 students taking part in the Southampton exhibition and 29 at the London Print Space. Projects are ongoing to raise our funds, such as a student led magazine called PentaPrism. The magazine was started by the class of 2014, and this year we are continuing their work . The submissions are open to the first, second and third year Photography (BA) HONS students at the University. Other small projects have been conducted, such as offering a service for passport styled pictures for students and the general public.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We have a large range of costs that need covering, from our end of year Catalogue, to renting the London PrintSpace and paying for printing costs. With our personal projects for fundraising, we are able to collect small funds to put towards our shows. However we can’t do it without some added support to accumulate the money we need to make our exhibitions the best they possibly could be!

We need to raise £750 to have the backing we need to make this project lift off the ground and achieve a first rate showcase that all can be proud of. As afore mentioned, the money raised will be put towards important aspects such as hiring the London PrintSpace and being able to produce a high end catalogue, and being able to help each individual present  work to their desired outcomes! It involves a lot of time and dedication but as the class of 2015 we are determined to present ourselves in the field of photography as enthusiastic artists always wishing to show the best of what we can achieve!

If you can't donate, dont feel like you cant help because you can! A simple share of this page with family and friends is one of the simplest ways to get the word to others!

WHAT YOU WILL RECIEVE

We want all of our contributors to feel apart of the final outcome, so first and foremost we invite you to our show 'Coda' so you can see what you have aided and what we have been spending three years working towards. And furthermore we are offering rewards such as being named as a contributor at our Solent show on a plaque, or recieving a print which you can choose from the selction of images featured in the video on this page. To redeem your print just contact us via the email below to notify us of what image you would like.

For more information, please do not hesitate to contact any one of us.  You can contact us through the site by clicking on our icons below the video, or with the emails listed below.

And please visit our Facebook page, which you can find further down the page. There we will be posting updates of our work towards our shows, and also thanking all those that contribute. We can't do it without you! 

SITES

Here are the links you need to see the work being produced by the PentaPrism magazine, and the work being submitted for it! Plus the emails listed below is how you can contact us with any questions and letting us know of any prints you would like to redeem. Thank you!

https://www.facebook.com/pentaprismpaper?fref=ts 

http://pentaprismpaper.tumblr.com/

severynszymaszek@gmail.com 

 nataliecintra@hotmail.co.uk 

 scaryscizwig@hotmail.co.uk

story:
The campaign is over but you can still contribute for the continuation of The Atlas of Beauty . Your support is really important because it will help me reach more places of the earth and show more diversity of our amazing planet. Our world really needs an Atlas of Beauty and we can create it together. 


What is The Atlas of Beauty

First of all, let me introduce myself: I’m Mihaela Noroc, a 29 years old photographer from Romania. In the past 2 years I traveled around the world, with my own small savings, photographing hundreds of women and creating a project called The Atlas of Beauty.

My goal is to show that beauty is everywhere and is not about race, money or trends, but more about being yourself, natural and authentic.

     #1 Romania

Today more and more women feel a pressure to look in a certain way, but I think we are beautiful, if we treasure what makes us unique.

The Atlas of Beauty became viral on the internet and major publications, from all around the world, wrote about it. Now I have the chance to make my statement heard so it's very important to continue my project.      

   

   #2 Ethiopia                                                                 #3 Colombia

I have to travel at least one year to gather enough images for publishing a comprehensive Atlas, but I really need your support to do this journey.

I plan to visit all continents, except Atarctica, and I will make my exact route based on your votes. I will go in both modern and traditional countries. I will cover different kind of environments from cities, villages and remote areas to show the diversity of our planet, through portraits of women. 

Now millions of people will see my photos and together we can send a powerful message to the world. We can show that beauty is in our differences and we should all be proud of ourselves. 

     #4 Ecuador

Costs for continuing The Atlas of Beauty

A photographic journey around the world is not cheap, but I’m used to get along with what I have, because I love what I do. 

To make the project properly for one year I will need at least 27,000 USD. My expenses are explained below:

I will need around 20 plane tickets, some of them on long distances. Beside this, I will need ground transportation, accommodation and food. My budget also have to cover insurances, visa fees, and, of course, unexpected expenses.

When I will take photos in communities in need, I will try to help as much as I can, offering gifts and sharing the story with people that can support. 

I will have to update my photo gear buying a new lens and 2 resistant external hard drives. I will also need some accessories to add to my DSLR, for filming my journey.

A part of my budget has to cover the productions of the perks + Indiegogo fee and bank charges. 

        #5 Cuba

Now that I reached the funding goal, I can cover the expenses listed above. 

But more funds I raise, more countries and diversity I will capture. The extra funds are essential for the quality of the project so each contribution is still very important. 

With your support, I will explore more areas of the world.   

I will also be able to offer more support when visiting communities in need.

Sometime I will be able to rent a car or hire a guide to go in more remote places.

        #6  Iran

 

     #7 Romania                                                               #8 Colombia

Rewards for your contribution

For 30 USD you will receive The Atlas of Beauty E-book by e-mail, in a few days. It contains 105 pages of photos and short stories from my first journey.

For 60 USD  you will receive the The Atlas of Beauty E-book, in a few days, and a Postcard, sent by me to your mail-box, sometime during my journey.

For 100 USD you will receive the E-book, the Postcard and you will become a member of The Atlas of Beauty Community. As a member of the community you will always be a close friend of the project and your name will be written on The First Edition of The Atlas of Beauty (the hardcover book that will be published in 2016, after my journey)

        #9 Amazon Rainforest

            #10  Peru

          #11 USA

The Impact of the project

The Atlas of Beauty has been featured in major publications of the world. This coverage offers us the opportunity to send our message to more people.

But this is just the beginning. If I will have your support I will capture much more diversity. Together we will continue to show that beauty means to be yourself, to be proud of your roots, to cultivate what you have, instead of being disappointed about something that you don’t have.

Beauty is in our differences and uniqueness. Now I’m saying it trough words, but if I will have your support, I will “say” it better through my photos.

     

       #12 Chile                                                                       #13 Uzbekistan


           #14  Tibetan Plateau, China

            #15 Ethiopia

   

             #16 Ecuador                                                        #17 Cuba

             #18 USA

           #19 Peru

Risks and challenges

In my previous journey I had dangerous moments, hard days of working, exhausting routes, unfriendly viruses, but I will do it again, with all my passion. This time I will have more experience and more confidence, knowing that wonderful people from all around the world are supporting me.

 


         #20 Romania                                                        #21 Ecuador

Other ways you can help

Any contribution is important and will help me to continue. But you can also support me by sharing my story with your friends and letting the world know about The Atlas of Beauty Campaign. 

             #22   Brazil                     

   

           #23 Uzbekistan                                                      #24 Tibetan Plateau, China


Together we can show to the world that beauty is everywhere. Thank you very much for your support!

important to continue my project.            #2 Ethiopia                                                                 #3 Colombia

I have to travel at
least one year to gather enough images for publishing a comprehensive Atlas, but
I really need your support to do this journey. 
I plan to visit all continents, except Atarctica, and I will make my exact route based on your votes. I will go in both modern and traditional countries. I will cover different kind of environments from cities, villages and remote areas to show the diversity of our planet, through portraits of women. 
Now millions of people
will see my photos and together we can send a powerful message to the world. We
can show that beauty is in our differences and we should all be proud of
ourselves. 


     #4 Ecuador
Costs for continuing The Atlas of Beauty
A photographic journey
around the world is not cheap, but I’m used to get along with what I have,
because I love what I do. 
To make the project
properly for one year I will need at least 27,000 USD. My expenses are explained below:




I will need around 20
plane tickets, some of them on long distances. Beside this, I will need ground
transportation, accommodation and food. My budget also have to cover
insurances, visa fees, and, of course, unexpected expenses. 
When I will take photos
in communities in need, I will try to help as much as I can, offering gifts and sharing
the story with people that can support.  
I will have to update
my photo gear buying a new lens and 2 resistant external hard drives. I will
also need some accessories to add to my DSLR, for filming my journey. 
A part of my budget has
to cover the productions of the perks + Indiegogo fee and bank charges. 
        #5 Cuba
Now that I reached the funding goal, I can cover the expenses listed above. 
But more funds I raise, more countries and diversity I will capture. The extra funds are essential for the quality of the project so each contribution is still very important. 
With your support, I will explore more areas of the world.   
I will also be able to
offer more support when visiting communities in need.
Sometime I will be able to rent a car or hire a guide to go in more remote places.
        #6  Iran



  

     #7 Romania                                                               #8 Colombia


Rewards
for your contribution
For 30 USD you will receive The Atlas of Beauty E-book by e-mail, in a few days. It contains 105 pages of photos and short stories
from my first journey. 
For 60 USD  you will
receive the The Atlas of Beauty E-book, in a few days, and a Postcard, sent by me to your mail-box, sometime during
my journey. 
For
100 USD you
will receive the E-book, the
Postcard and you will become a member of The Atlas of Beauty Community.
As a member of the community you will always be a close friend of the project
and your name will be written on The First Edition of The Atlas of Beauty (the
hardcover book that will be published in 2016, after my journey)
        #9 Amazon Rainforest


            #10  Peru          #11 USA


The Impact of the project
The Atlas of Beauty has been featured in major publications of the world. This coverage offers us the opportunity to send our message to more people.

But this is just the beginning. If I will have your support I will capture much more diversity. Together we will continue to show that beauty means to be yourself, to be proud of your roots, to cultivate what you have, instead of being disappointed about something that you don’t have.
Beauty is in our differences and uniqueness. Now I’m saying it trough words, but if I will have your support, I will “say” it better through my photos.
      
       #12 Chile                                                                       #13 Uzbekistan


           #14  Tibetan Plateau, China



            #15 Ethiopia


    



             #16 Ecuador                                                        #17 Cuba


             #18 USA


           #19 Peru




Risks and challenges
In my previous journey I had dangerous moments, hard days of working,
exhausting routes, unfriendly viruses, but I will do it again, with all my
passion. This time I will have more experience and more confidence, knowing
that wonderful people from all around the world are supporting me.

  




         #20 Romania                                                        #21 Ecuador


Other ways you can help

Any contribution is
important and will help me to continue. But you can also support me by sharing
my story with your friends and letting the world know about The Atlas of Beauty
Campaign. 

             #22   Brazil                     









    





           #23 Uzbekistan                                                      #24 Tibetan Plateau, China




Together we can show to the world that beauty is everywhere. Thank you very much for your support!

story:
WE ARE ORGANIZING A SERIES OF TOURS AROUND SOUTH AMERICA ON OUR HIPPIE VAN.

TO LET PEOPLE KNOW ABOUT THE PHOTOGRAPHIC MUSEUM OF HUMANITY, THE FIRST INTERNET MUSEUM DEDICATED TO PHOTOGRAPHY. A SPACE WHERE PHOTOGRAPHERS WILL HAVE THE POSSIBILITY TO SHOW THEIR TALENT. A PLACE WHERE PEOPLE, REGARDLESS OF THEIR AGE, CULTURE, RELIGION OR NATIONALITY, WILL HAVE THE POSSIBILITY TO LEARN.

WE ARE A GROUP OF YOUNG FOLKS DEVELOPING AN INDEPENDENT PROJECT WITH IDEAS AND OWN FUNDS. HELP US PROMOTING THE MUSEUM BY MEANS OF OUR TOURS AND ENJOY OUR PERKS. YOUR CONTRIBUTION CAN REALLY HELP US OUT.

THE NEXT ROAD TRIP WILL BE THE BRAZIL TOUR 2013. FOLLOW US AT:

www.photographicmuseum.com 

www.facebook.com/phmuseum

 

About the Photographic Museum of Humanity

Photographic Museum of Humanity is an artistic start-up founded in between Bologna and Buenos Aires in august 2011.

The project aims to create and develop the first online museum dedicated to photography, made with the most interesting works submitted to our web platform by the professional photographers of our artistic community. 

The first Museum actually accessible to everyone from every corner of the world, at any time, for free. A place where people will have the possibility to learn about photography and its universal language.

 

The South American Tours

We travel around South America on the Museum Hippie Van. To let people know about our independent project. To spread the word of photography. To tell everybody something new is happening. To let people know they can enjoy the first internet museum dedicated to photography. Always and for free.
 
We started our road trips 6 months ago with the PMH 2012 Bolivia Tour. We drove all the way from Buenos Aires to La Paz. The Blue Magical Van in the role of the Museum, which cancels the distances reaching the most in-the-middle-of-nowhere corners of our planet. Ourselves in the role of ourselves.
 
After the Bolivia Tour 2012 we organized a fund-raising event in Bologna, collecting around USD 4,000 to finance a cultural association realizing a book made with the work of 50 photographers to promote Bolivian photography within and outside the country.
 
The upcoming South American Tours are:
 
BRASIL TOUR 2013: confirmed 25/01/2013 to 20/02/2013
CHILE TOUR 2013: scheduled October-November 2013
ARGENTIAN TOUR 2014: scheduled January-February 2014
 
 
Here you can find:
  
- an article written by Giuseppe Oliverio, the Museum founder, about the Bolivia Tour 2012: http://www.photographicmuseum.com/blog/our-news/the-museum-on-the-road/ 
 
- a link to the fund raising event: http://www.photographicmuseum.com/blog/our-news/museum-for-bolivian-photography
 
- a link to the Facebook Fan Page of the Bolivian Photography Book we financed: https://www.facebook.com/FotografiaBoliviana
 
 

Why Funding our project

Our idea is to promote and bring to everyone the power of art. A language that is universal and promote integration and multiculturalism. An instrument that emancipates and support changes. Our Museum will be the first actually accessible to everyone, from any corner of the world and for free. A space where photographers will have the possibility to show their talent and where people, regardless of their culture, education, religion or nationality, will have the possibility to learn.

Our road trips are fundamental in developing our project becuase they are the most effective way to make people know and talk about us. We are an independent project with no Private Equity Fund or Angel Invstor supporting us. We are simply a group of young folks developing the project with our own funds and ideas. Your support can make the difference.

 

This is our Manifesto. It explains our philosophy and how our project can help people to live art in a free and democratic way.

"We believe photography is a powerful medium of expression, a creative way to depict life. We believe people are unique and there is so much talent among us. It is just there, and yet almost nobody sees it. We believe there are many things happening all over the world, all the time. Somewhere, somehow. These things are just there, and yet almost nobody sees them. We want this to change.

We believe a museum is a place where people have the opportunity to learn and be inspired. There are museums everywhere but millions of people do not have the chance to travel the world and visit them. These museums are just there, and yet almost nobody sees them. We want this to change.

We believe that when people visit a museum they should have the possibility to share their thoughts and feelings. Communicate with each other and exchange visions and ideas. These opportunities exist, are just there and yet almost nobody sees them. We want this to change. 

And we are going to change it. Together.

Our Photographic Museum will be the first Museum actually accessible to everyone from every corner of the world, at any time and always for free. A Museum filled with the best photos shared within an artistic community where everyone will be free to display their talents. A space where visitors will have the chance to participate and exchange their opinions and reactions.

This Museum will allow us to get closer to the photographic arts. And by means of the photographic arts, by means of those thousands of photos shot by photographers of different nationalities and backgrounds around the world, we will be able to see what contemporary society is about. Which moments, events and people characterize the world today. Which facts, situations, emotions and stories happen in our time. Somewhere, somehow. 

They will be there and everyone will see them.

It will be the first Museum made by the people. An open vision of many. A place where visitors, regardless of their age, culture, education, religion and nationality, will have the possibility to learn and expand their knowledge. For our generation and the generations to come. 

It will be a change.

It will be the Photographic Museum of Humanity."
 

How can you help

- Fund our Museum road trips and enjoy our perks 

- Share our website: www.photographicmuseum.com

- Help our videos go viral: www.vimeo.com/53858514

 
Thank you!! Every form of help is sincerly appreciated by us and our artistic community.

story:
About my project the Mark Studner Exhibit:

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting my solo exhibit at The Center in Long Beach in May & June 2014. This is a very exciting time for me and an opportunity to re-launch my photography career. But I am coming up short.  $3,000 to be exact.  So I am coming to you, my friends and admirers of my photography, to help bring my exhibit to life. The $3,000 is the remaining amount required to professionally print my selected 30 images onto beautiful, large canvases for the exhibit.  I know nothing in life comes for free and I have never been one to expect or ask for handouts in my life. In return for your loving support, I am offering some very cool perks. Please take a moment to have a look. 

This exhibit will be a very inspirational showing. I was born with Cerebral Palsy, a condition in which doctors believed and said I would never live a productive life.  I set out to prove them wrong and took up photography as my outlet for expression at the age of 10 years old and have never looked back.  Unfortunately, I, like many artists, have been impacted by the economy. This will be the first show I have done in 15 years!

Through your support, we will be able to provide a source of hope and inspiration. I am not just showing my photographs, but aiming to use my art to give inspiration to people with any disabilities or any of life’s barriers, and show that people can triumph.  

This exhibit will give my work the opportunity to be experienced by 100’s of people by the LGBTQ community and anyone else who wishes to be inspired.  My exhibit will include a “meet and greet” reception at The Center on Saturday, May 24, 2014 from 5pm to 9pm, where I would love to connect with all of you, face to face, surrounded by the true story of my life; my art. The Center is at 2017 E. Fourth St in Long Beach, CA 90814.

Personally, this exhibit is a testimony of my strength, my love for photography and the people that I meet because of it, and for the belief in myself where I did not give up on a dream that was forming for most of my life. So, I am asking all of you to please make any donation you see fit to turn my dream into a reality.

Thank you.

Love,

Mark

Portrait of Mark Studner - graphite pencil drawing by David J. Vanderpool Copyright 2014 

About My Life and Photography-

My photography has spanned 35+ years since I first picked up a camera. I went to a handicap school until 6th grade where I found my talent with photography. Just for me picking up a camera at that age was an amazing achievement because I was born with Cerebral Palsy (CP) which affected my speech and my motor skill of walking and holding. But still, I had a minor form of CP. My mom encouraged me to follow my dreams and as soon as people in the community noticed my talent I was on my way to success despite of my disability.

 I was the yearbook photographer for all Junior High & High School and received an AA degree in photo-journalism in college. I soon found myself at KROQ as a personal photographer for the radio station taking photographs of bands such as Duran Duran, R.E.M., Billy Idol and others. I also worked out of my home photo studio and a dark room. I soon had many exhibits around Los Angeles in such places as Rage and Figs West Hollywood, and Van Go’s Ear in Venice Beach. Due to their popularity, numerous Los Angeles based magazines found me and put my work on their covers including Edge, Frontiers, Fab and many others. I have worked with model and talent agencies giving me the opportunity to photograph many people before they sprung to stardom such as one James Franco which I photographed many times.

Photography has brought me unlimited experiences that few would never dream of doing. It brought me people that would have never crossed my path in life, and friendships that will last for a lifetime. It gave me something to live for when my mom died, and there is not a day that goes by without photography touching me. My mom sacrificed many, many things in her life to see that I became the best photographer that I could. Overcoming obstacles are almost a daily occurrence. But as my mom showed me, by her faith in me and my photography is that if you have the passion for something, anything is possible.

How I became involved with The Center

After giving up my photography studio due to the economy, I immersed myself in helping other people with disabilities. I found myself at New Horizons in North Hills for a new start in life, where they help people with disabilities. Soon after I found a job through their programs and then became a Board Member and event photographer for the growth of their clients.  Next, through a publisher of a magazine which I shot for, they wrote an article about growing up handicap, finding my sexual identity, and also becoming a well-known photographer here in Los Angeles. The Center saw that article in August 2013, and asked me if I would be a part of this new LGBTQ Special Needs Group, where I am still today. I was just asked to take over for Kyle, the developer of the group, once he leaves for new ventures. What a big honor! First I was immediately apart of The Center’s film festival because they saw my James Franco pictures and was asked to put some up for the event. It was a success and that is how I got involved with The Center.

The Center in Long Beach is a non-profit community center whose mission statement is “As the central core of the Greater Long Beach LGBT communities we offer assistance and provide education about emotional and physical health, housing, cultural and social activities, and legal and social justice. We advocate for the inclusion of all with no judgment or restrictions based on sexual orientation or gender identity.” It is formally called The LGBTQ Center Long Beach. I am proud to be showing my work in their gallery and lobby where people of all race, age, religion, sexual preferences come for support, knowledge, information, testing, and help for many everyday problems.

 ***Lana was a regular friends that photographed at my studio with me very often.***

My personal thoughts on my campaign: 

I am very excited to once again, after many years of personal growth in life, that I am coming back home to my life’s gift and talent as a photographer. Through all the years of learning through my experiences,  my passion for my craft, got me through many tough times in my life. I am honoring the art of photography and all its magical healing properties which it had on my life. I thought this showing is very appropriate to have at this time because of all my life knowledge which I learned from being an individual with Cerebral Palsy and experience as a photographer and a sort time without. I want to share to all the people which I might have touched and believed in me, my photography and how I overcame the odds to be a photographer once again. This is a true blessing in having this chance to let me to share my photography with the public again. This special exhibit is a direct result of my hard work of  overcoming the most obstacles on my way on making it. I believe that my achievements was a direct results of my passion, which now will be a beacon for others with disabilities to do the same, and also to have a place such as The Center to have this platform to do this great event with great people. Thank you again for helping this to be a reality. Love Mark

 Can you Help Me to Spread the Word!

Please share this campaign anywhere you can! Post it on social media, in forums, or wherever else you can think of! There are share tools built right into the campaign and after you pledge there are many options for sharing there as well. Please help me out as it would mean a lot to me!

What this Exhibit is All About

This is my first official “funding” campaign that I did. You all know that I do not ask for many things, but I know that, to do this right, I have to ask all of you to make this event happen. I know that I have a lot of friends that touched my life, and I touch their's in many ways. This is how I can give back a little bit of that friendship and love. This is the very first time in my life that I feel that something is guiding me through this and sending me the right people, at the right time to help me with it! This event is going to bring people together, make people aware of other people in need, while creating a bunch of new friendships and having fun doing it! If my photography and my heart, can create such an amazing thing like that – I AM GOING FOR IT! I always felt that The Center is a very special place, and I can’t think of a more better place than that, in making miracles happen. I believe that I still have my gift of photography for a reason, and I am thrilled to share this event with you, because of you, IT’S HAPPENING! I can reach my goal with you, and I hope that Eric Katigbak will meet his wish in find a kidney donor. Thank you for making this happen. I will also be there for you. Please contribute and see all the wonderful things it brings.

THANK YOU AGAIN!

"Just creating new Hopes & Dreams through my photography. It's all about paying it forward!"

support, knowledge, information, testing, and help for many everyday problems. ***Lana was a regular friends that photographed at my studio with me very often.***My personal thoughts on my campaign: I am very excited to once again, after many years of personal growth in life, that I am coming back home to my life’s gift and talent as a photographer. Through all the years of learning through my experiences,  my passion for my craft, got me through many tough times in my life. I am honoring the art of photography and all its magical healing properties which it had on my life. I thought this showing is very appropriate to have at this time because of all my life knowledge which I learned from being an individual with Cerebral Palsy and experience as a photographer and a sort time without. I want to share to all the people which I might have touched and believed in me, my photography and how I overcame the odds to be a photographer once again. This is a true blessing in having this chance to let me to share my photography with the public again. This special exhibit is a direct result of my hard work of  overcoming the most obstacles on my way on making it. I believe that my achievements was a direct results of my passion, which now will be a beacon for others with disabilities to do the same, and also to have a place such as The Center to have this platform to do this great event with great people. Thank you again for helping this to be a reality. Love Mark Can you Help Me to Spread the Word!
Please share this campaign anywhere you can! Post it on social media, in forums, or wherever else you can think of! There are share tools built right into the campaign and after you pledge there are many options for sharing there as well. Please help me out as it would mean a lot to me!What this Exhibit is All About
This is my first official “funding” campaign that I did. You all know that I do not ask for many things, but I know that, to do this right, I have to ask all of you to make this event happen. I know that I have a lot of friends that touched my life, and I touch their's in many ways. This is how I can give back a little bit of that friendship and love. This is the very first time in my life that I feel that something is guiding me through this and sending me the right people, at the right time to help me with it! This event is going to bring people together, make people aware of other people in need, while creating a bunch of new friendships and having fun doing it! If my photography and my heart, can create such an amazing thing like that – I AM GOING FOR IT! I always felt that The Center is a very special place, and I can’t think of a more better place than that, in making miracles happen. I believe that I still have my gift of photography for a reason, and I am thrilled to share this event with you, because of you, IT’S HAPPENING! I can reach my goal with you, and I hope that Eric Katigbak will meet his wish in find a kidney donor. Thank you for making this happen. I will also be there for you. Please contribute and see all the wonderful things it brings.THANK YOU AGAIN!"Just creating new Hopes & Dreams through my photography. It's all about paying it forward!"

story:
Hello There!

Hello friends, family and all those interested in supporting Tailings! For those of you that are new to my photographic work, my name is Cebe Loomis and I am a visual artist and social documentarian. I specialize in ethnographic photography essays and my research interests include practices of visual anthropology, place-making, cultural geography and collective memory formation. I earned my Bachelors Degree in Anthropology from Vassar College and I am currently pursuing my Masters of the Fine Arts in Social Documentation at University of California, Santa Cruz.

I have created this IndieGoGo in the hopes of securing funds to help support summer fieldwork and post-production costs for my thesis project, Tailings. I have sought out grants, awards, scholarships and other third party funding sources, but that hustle is never guaranteed! So, I am turning to you friendly folks to donate what you can to help get my project off the ground. Whether you want to support the artist (me!), the work (Tailings), both or just love giving, any amount is greatly appreciated. Please read a bit about Tailings below and hopefully you will be inspired to help me complete my project!

 

Project Introduction

Perched on the highest eastern slope of the Virginia Range, Mount Davidson, in Storey County, Nevada, sits a town of 855 inhabitants and over 150 years of history. Named Virginia City through a folklore story involving the prospector, “Old Virginny Finney”, this boomtown was home to the Comstock Lode of 1859, the United States’ first major silver ore discovery. Declared a National Historic Landmark district in 1961 (presently the largest landmark in the United States), Virginia City stands historically preserved, boasting authentic 1860’s attractions that continue to perform and re-discover histories and traditions of the colonial “Wild West”.

Expected to decay and be left abandoned like the many ghost towns scattered through the landscapes of the West, Virginia City survives because of its robust tourist industry and its small, dedicated population. When walking along C Street, the synthesis of past and present is obvious. Opera houses used for regional punk festivals or the international camel races filmed with iPhones, Virginia City’s demonstrative celebration of its Western folklore sets the stage for historical imagination, a doing of human history. What does it mean to live in this history? Whose histories are being performed? What do these histories look, feel and sound like?

Through the use of analogue photography, ambient and interview based sound montages, as well as ethnographic text, “Tailings” unpacks how and why the 1850’s boomtown of Virginia City defies expectations of time, as well as questions the colonial methods Virginia City has employed in order to survive. Executed in a self-published book, with an accompanying moving-image piece, “Tailings” relays the voices and narratives of the peoples and environments present in Virginia City, as well as those that have continually been absent from the dominant, colonial History.

 

On a Personal Note

In the mid 1850’s, my great-great-grandfather, Andrew Frandsen, emigrated from Denmark to the lands of Western Nevada to work as a hay hand and sheepherder on a ranch in the Truckee Meadows. Andrew eventually became one of the most successful sheepmen in the region and established a well-rooted life for him and his family to come. As the daughter to Andrew’s great-grandson, a born and bred Reno local, I have grown up with an appreciation and wonderment of the Nevadan landscape. From vast, pastel deserts to awesome mountainous formations that graze the true blue skies, Nevada has always humbled me to the environmental marvels of the continental United States. This natural landscape is impossible to dismiss and is intricately woven into the cultural landscapes across the state. Although Nevada has come to be famous for its "unorthodox" experiences, such as “Sin City” Las Vegas or legalized prostitution in infamous brothels such as Mustang Ranch, Nevada’s histories and traditions are steeped in complex relationships with its harsh and grand landscapes.

The hidden narratives and histories that constitute a distinctly Nevadan identity personally inspire Tailings, challenging its readers not familiar with the state to learn, question and experience a place deeply rich in Native and colonial history. Although “Tailings” works to uncover Nevadan histories and cultures to strangers of the state, the project also presents a specialized, detailed and visceral account of Virginia City for the local populations of Nevada. As a social documentarian passionate about illuminating stories often unseen, Tailings offers an insight into a place whose history has been shaped by monumental landscape, indigenous spirit, colonial oppression, natural resource exploitation and the opportunistic imagination of the American Frontier.

 

Funding Allocation

Amount          Description

17%                Film cost and film development 

18%                Fieldwork transportation

27%                Fieldwork living costs

38%                Publication/distribution of final multi-media photography book

--

$8,500           Total

 

Links to my photographic work:

www.cebeloomis.com

www.inmyyesterday.blogspot.com

story:
****I've added two new perks for Stake Presidents, Bishops, Relief Society Presidents, Primary Presidents, Young Men and/or Young Women leaders. Buy calendars in bulk at significantly reduced prices.****

(Look to the right to see all the perks/options that are available)>>>>>>

****Buy Five or more calendars and be entered to win a free workshop****

Your name will be placed in a drawing for a one-on-one photo workshop with me, where we can discuss and photograph one of the local (Mesa, Gilbert, Phoenix) Temples, or we can head into the desert to work on your landscape photography.
We'll spend up to three hours where we can discuss and work on photographic techniques & concepts from beginning to advanced.
The workshop is transferable. If you're not into photography, give it to somebody who is.
Everybody who purchased 5 calendars or more (or dollar equivalent) is eligible.

Introduction

My name is Richard Webb. I'm a native of Arizona.  I have a degree in Commercial Photography from Northern Arizona University and have been a freelance contributor and contract photographer for Arizona Highways magazine for many years.

I've learned that strong compositions, beautiful lighting, and dramatic skies make the best landscape images. The same elements also make for amazing Temple images. Creating powerful and inspiring images of LDS Temples has become a passion of mine.

Selling prints through Deseret Book and other LDS retail outlets has given me the chance to build an audience, connect with fans, and gain valuable feedback. The feedback I've received most is that Arizonans want a calendar of their Temples!

Objective

My goal now is to create a 14-month calendar featuring the five LDS Temples in Arizona. The calendar will actually have 16 Temple images, including the cover and an image on the year-at-a-glance page. It will make a great Christmas gift.

Here are the images.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>        Look to the right and click on one or more of the perks to buy. Get one   calendar or many, or get a print of any of the calendar images.  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

Below are the images and the months they'll represent in the calendar.

Cover - Mesa Monsoon Clouds (won't include watermark)

December 2015 - Phoenix Before The Storm (won't include watermark)

January 2016 - Gilbert Entrance Dusk (won't include watermark)

February 2016 - Snowflake Waterfall (won't include watermark)

March 2016 - Gila Valley Storm (won't include watermark)

April 2016 - Mesa Bottlebrush (won't include watermark)

May 2016 - Phoenix Mountain Morning (won't include watermark)

June 2016 - Gilbert Dust Storm (won't include watermark)

July 2016 - Snowflake Sunset Reflections (won't include watermark)

August 2016 - Gilbert Lightning (won't include watermark)

September 2016 - Phoenix Monsoon Clouds (won't include watermark)

October 2016 - Gila Valley Dusk (won't include watermark)

November 2016 - Gilbert Fall Morning (won't include watermark)

December 2016 - Mesa Christmas Light Morning (won't include watermark)

January 2017 - Snowflake Sunrise Silhouette (won't include watermark)

Year-at-a-glance page - Mesa Blue Sunset (won't include watermark)

The purpose of this campaign is to fund the production and distribution of the calendar.  By backing this project you can receive one or more copies of the calendar for yourself, or to give as gifts.

Each page of the calendar will be 8 1/2" x 11", but the actual Temple images will be 8" x 10" in size. After you're done with a particular month, feel free to remove the image from the calendar and put it in a frame. This is an economical way to display Temple images throughout your home.

Producing a quality calendar is expensive. There are significant upfront costs for setup and the actual printing. Fortunately, in this case, the images are already made. I will deliver digital files to the printer early in the campaign, and then pay for the actual printing after the campaign ends.

My goal for this campaign is to raise enough funds to set up and print the calendar; pay for materials, postage, and labor; and pay all associated (Indiegogo and PayPal) fees and applicable taxes.

I hope that you'll continue to check on the campaign and keep sharing with those who might be interested.

Bonus sale on fine art giclee prints

As an added bonus/perk I'm offering each of the images on the calendar as giclee prints on paper and canvas at specially reduced prices. Available sizes are 16x20, 20x25, and 24x30.

Your Contribution

Your contribution, or backing, to this campaign is crucial. The more calendars I can print and the more successful this campaign is, the more likely I will be to continue to do this in the future. I would like to produce and share more Temple images that I can offer as prints and on future calendars.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.

Please get the word out and let people know about this campaign. Share it on social media, email, and tell your friends and family. Also, use the Indiegogo share tools. Thanks for your help!

story:
Update:

We've been working hard to get you this sample page for a taste of the interactive experience.

Instructions:

  1. Download the "Aurasma" app. 
    Get it on the Google Play Store and the App Store.
  2. Follow the channel "bkh.leung".
  3. Open or download the sample page.
  4. Frame and scan the moose image in the top left of the page.

Brian's Story: Too often dreams are left unrealized. 2014 was a tough year for my family and I. After recovering from a surgery for a ruptured Achilles tendon and seeing my dad go through surgery for lung cancer at Sunnybrook Hospital, it dawned that dreams should never pass you by.

Two of my dreams:
  1. Go on an adventure (drive across Canada)
  2. Publish my own magazine
With your help, these dreams won't pass me by.
Pictures and stories collected from my cross country trip will be published in my own magazine.
Hopefully the photos and magazine will inspire you to either realize your own dreams or go on an adventure.
If you need a push to go out there, I'd highly recommend the Adventurers perk.

Eric's Story: I met Brian last summer through a mutual friend. When he started this Indiegogo Campaign and asked me for support, I realized how much it mirrored my own year. I quit my full-time job in June to start my own multimedia company. Since then, I've had my ups and downs, going through the trials and tribulations of being a business owner (and not getting a cheque every two weeks).

Inspired by his enthusiasm and bravery, I have decided to join him on this trip and document it all. Brian's willingness to step out of his comfort zone reflects on what I have been doing the past 6 months.

I will produce a documentary about our adventure by the end of the year. We have a few ideas on what both the magazine and documentary will focus on but we will also see where the road takes us. We may depart on this trip with some ideas and come back with something completely different.

This is where I need your help. I only have half the equipment I need to make sure this film is produced correctly. The Glidecam vest that I'll need to purchase costs $1600. And not having a regular 9-5 job while running my own business leaves my wallet quite empty. I wish to ask for some help in making this documentary come to life.

Below is our Indiegogo campaign. The Viewers perk will exclusively help fund my documentary gear. Backers of this perk will have access to an early digital release of the film.

On top of the film, I will also be helping out with the magazine. Photography has been my passion for the last 8 years so it only makes sense for me to be involved. The magazine will be full of photos and stories from our adventure and the people we meet. It will also come with special pages that have interactive video content that we've shot.  So please help fund the magazine as well by contributing to the Readers perk. There is a $10 Readers perk for a digital copy and a $25 Readers perk for a physical copy of the magazine.

Allow me to thank everyone in advance. Your donations and words of encouragement are greatly appreciated. I'm very excited to plan and go on this trip in the summer. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for me that I cannot miss.


Where will the money go?
The money raised will go toward renting camera equipment, the car, fuel, and production cost of the magazine. (I'll be camping instead of staying in hostels or motels to save money.)
Know someone who's affected by cancer? Check out the Givers perk: 50% of all donations for this perk will be given to cancer research!
The Viewers perk will directly support the production costs of the documentary.

Timeline
Mid-February:
end of campaign
Feb to mid-May:
plan the trip, source publisher and materials for the magazine 
Last week of May:
GO-TIME!
Mid-June:
fly back from Vancouver
September:
deliver Adventurers perks
July:
Deliver the Writers perks
Aug to Nov:
Magazine production
November:
Deliver Contributors perks
December:
Deliver Readers & Viewers perks
Don't have Paypal? Did you know that you don't need a Paypal account to contribute?
Here's how:
  1. When you get to the PayPal screen, you'll see up top "Choose a Way to Pay"
  2. Select the second option: "Pay with a debit or credit card"
  3. Complete the form
  4. When you get to the checkbox that says: "Save this information with a PayPal account. It's easy and free to sign up. Learn more about PayPal", uncheck the box.
  5. Click "review and continue" to continue with a payment using a credit card.
  6. Click on the "continue without logging in" link

Don't have Paypal? Did you know that you don't need a Paypal account to contribute?


Here's how:


When you get to the PayPal screen, you'll see up top "Choose a Way to Pay"

Select the second option: "Pay with a debit or credit card"

Complete the form

When you get to the checkbox that says: "Save this information with a PayPal account. It's easy and free to sign up. Learn more about PayPal", uncheck the box.

Click "review and continue" to continue with a payment using a credit card.

Click on the "continue without logging in" link

story:
On a weekly basis I photograph a child who has been just diagnosed with cancer, going through treatment, in remission, or at the end of life. My mission is to make the shoot a dream shoot by finding out what the child loves and incorporating that into the magical day. I don't charge the families and provide them with all the photographs taken as well as a canvas print of their favorite image. These pledges will help support my passion and project creating images of heroes and hope! I have done things like rent a cool car, buy dance outfits, have local sports stars stop by, use local horses, barns, gardens, etc, to help make their photoshoots magical. Sometimes it's as simple as a pink tutu or a baseball jersey for the child to really light up and feel special!

Your funds will help a child have dream shoot and provide the family with lasting memories. These photographs capture a spirit and beauty that can change your life!

My challenges arise when I need to spend money out of my personal account. As a part-time night shift worker and a stay at home mom I often can not fund these special requests. In order to give the children an extra special experience funds are sometimes needed that I can't provide.
story_txt:
On a weekly basis I photograph a child who has been just diagnosed with cancer, going through treatment, in remission, or at the end of life. My mission is to make the shoot a dream shoot by finding out what the child loves and incorporating that into the magical day. I don't charge the families and provide them with all the photographs taken as well as a canvas print of their favorite image. These pledges will help support my passion and project creating images of heroes and hope! I have done things like rent a cool car, buy dance outfits, have local sports stars stop by, use local horses, barns, gardens, etc, to help make their photoshoots magical. Sometimes it's as simple as a pink tutu or a baseball jersey for the child to really light up and feel special! Your funds will help a child have dream shoot and provide the family with lasting memories. These photographs capture a spirit and beauty that can change your life! 
My challenges arise when I need to spend money out of my personal account. As a part-time night shift worker and a stay at home mom I often can not fund these special requests. In order to give the children an extra special experience funds are sometimes needed that I can't provide.

story:
205 YEARS


When four people from different backgrounds decide to return to formal education to acquire new skills and extend their knowledge,they will as a matter of course form new friendships. This photography exhibition is the culmination of three years studying, and the professional relationship formed between people who have opted to step out of their comfort zone, and backed by the encouragement of tutors who could see their hidden potential, refine their artistic style and finally show it  proudly to the world.

These four mature students Darren Foster, Sue Vincent, Laura Morris and Mel Tutton . (D.S.L.M) are living proof that returning to adult education will not melt your brain......Going to college will not make you feel old or out of place..... but will help you meet incredible people and best of all help bring out the talents that we all secretly know are present within  us.

Who Are We?


Darren Foster

"As a documentary photographer, finding the beauty in unconventional subjects has always fascinated me. Beauty to an extent is in the eye of the beholder and through photography I hope to share with others the hidden beauty that exists beneath a superficial surface.

  The majority of images I capture are taken using a large format film camera. Using this equipment has blended in seamlessly with the way I work, and when composing the images it has a controlling aesthetic.

I decided after developing a chronic illness, to make some changes to my life and return to education as a mature student. My desire was always to follow my passion for photography. Since starting the course I have developed many new skills and learned more about the industry, whilst at the same time expanding my education and ultimately gaining a degree".


Sue Vincent

"Born on the side of a Welsh mountain I can truly say I am Welsh born and bred !
I left school at 16 and because of family circumstances was unable to continue with my education. At the age of 60 I decided it was time to return
Borrowing and using a digital camera made me realise  that I could take photographs and my interest in photography started from there.
Going back into full time education was daunting , but I soon realised that age wasn't important, even as the eldest in the class, being able to interact with all ages was a wonderful education in itself.
 My original aim in returning to education had been to use my formal training in floristry to support my work in photography. The selection of colours and the way they interact, the forms that are created in floral art I felt would influence my work. But in my first year I was lured by the darkroom and into the world of black and white, the way the contrast replaces colour to define the image. Combining this discipline with portraiture and my love of people’s interaction became my photographic world".

                    




                                  

           

Laura Morris


Landscape and documentary photographer. Born and living most of her life in the North Wales area.this has had a great influence and been the motivation for most of her creative endeavors. There is an abundance of outstanding natural beauty and scenery in North Wales and capturing it has been a life changing experience.

I have lived most of my life in north Wales, where I have brought up my family. I have always had an interest in photography and would enjoy visiting galleries whenever I could. As my children have grown up, I found myself drawn back to photography and have returned to education after 35 years. This has been an amazing journey and I have learned so much that I’m so grateful for.



Mel Tutton


"This exhibition is a retrospective of my three years study at Coleg Llandrillo, it maps out the journey that I have been on and the landscapes that demanded my attention".

I have been photographing some of the great slate quarries of North Wales, as well as the wild mountains of Snowdonia, for the past three years, spending many hours alone with my camera, usually during winter in changeable weather. It has changed my life; I am now planning to move back to Snowdonia for a year to capture every season as it unfolds. I will do most of my work at sunrise and sunset, to capture the moment when the light is just right, my spirit is lifted just thinking about it. I have been looking for inspiration to the work of Colin Prior; his images of the Scottish highlands are wonderful. I dream of capturing the amazing mountains of North Wales, and hopefully someone one day will look at my work and be inspired.

 


The groups passion for their photography is infectious and the skills they have developed are here for all to see in their forthcoming exhibition. 205 Years. This show which opens on April 24th.

  To curate this exhibition has involved the kind help of many people. The Gallery (Oriel Colwyn) located in Theatr Colwyn, Colwyn Bay, has been made available by their curator. Paul Sampson, giving the group the best possible local space to show the high standard of their work. Costs can however can be prohibitive. A mature student soon realizes that the dedication to their studies and chosen medium, come at a personal financial cost. Income streams are low, but are gladly accepted as personal growth and skill bases built on to provide a positive future.

  This is where we are asking you if you would like to join in. Not only  are we inviting you to the opening night of our exhibition but:....... maybe you have a desire to learn......maybe you would like to unveil those inner skills.......maybe by being inspired by Laura, Sue ,Mel and Darren you to will seek out new challenges.


A few words from the college principal

Coleg Llandrillo Principal, Dafydd Evans, said: 

"The college is delighted to support these enterprising students in their forthcoming photographic exhibition. We are constantly encouraging our students to develop their entrepreneurial skills, and this event is an excellent example of this.

“Grŵp Llandrillo Menai aims to open the doors to new opportunities in Higher Education, and this includes more mature students, like Darren, Sue, Laura and Mel, who are looking for a change in direction in their careers. Good luck on your exciting, new venture.”

Laura and Sue meeting with the Principle  Dafydd Evans and Nick Hill from marketing...........Sue is behind the camera.....




What We Need & What You Get

Maybe you could help us out with our exhibition

Simply by sharing  this crowdfunding opportunity with others on your social media networks you could help us achieve our financial goal of covering the printing costs,  (archival quality printing is expensive), so is framing and mounting the prints to display them to their best effect.£500 pounds is our target and we would like your help to reach it. 

Join our "wall of fame" of sponsors and supporters helping us any way they can. This will be on show in the gallery along side our work. Don't worry if you want to remain anonymous, we will respect your privacy.

Their are perks to joining in with our fundraising. You could receive a signed print of your choice from one of the photographers, a lasting reminder of your contribution and a potential investment for the future, or you could have a portrait shot of yourself or a friend that will be professionally printed for you.

It can be your way of being part of this exhibition that celebrates what can be achieved by the hunger for further education.

Don't forget there are plenty of "share tools" on this Indiegogo site that will help us to promote this fundraising and the exhibition itself just by clicking a button.

Thank you for reading and hopefully participating.

DSLM205



Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate. If you can't, but would like to help, then help make this exhibition successful by sharing the link on social media. We hope you will tell your friends and family about us and help us to spread the word to anyone who you think would be interested. 

We thank you in advance for all your help

story:
Little Pete’s has been a Philadelphia institution since 1978 and it’s one of the few remaining diners in Philadelphia. It’s the type of place where the staff quickly remembers your name and the familiar “Hon” is often heard. With American society being overrun with chef driven restaurants and gastro pubs the good ole’ American diner is disappearing from the landscape.  There’s something comforting about a place that caters to all walks of life, where the poor and the wealthy, the young and the old, and the resident and tourist can sit down next to each other and engage in conversation.



  “I love diners and greasy spoons. Those "Greek" joints that serve hearty breakfasts and lunch. "Family style" restaurants where you could get a dinner for four with out maxing out the credit cards. The late or all night joints that serve food to "absorb" all the alcohol you drank or serve the denizens of the graveyard shift.” – Peter Bella, Chicago Now

  “Longtime staples of the city's restaurant scene, diners are slowly vanishing from sight. They're victims of dwindling revenue that can't keep pace with escalating rents or landlords ravenous for deep-pocketed drugstore chains and banks; changing neighborhood demographics; and aging owners' inability to attract buyers for 24/7 family businesses that the next generation doesn't want to take over.” Cara S Trager, Crains New York


The purpose of this project is to document my local diner that has meant so much to me over the last 20 years. Funding will provide me with a way to continue it and the printing and archiving of it. Eventually I hope to have a proper book published.

You can follow updates to this project here.
https://www.facebook.com/michael.penn.1291/medi...
