story:
After5 - A photographic journey in Kenya. A collection of photographs through the eyes of Kenyan / Kenyan based individuals.

I am Christina Engell Andersen. The founder of after5 magazine. A Kenyan based creative magazine for photographers, illustrators and graphical designers living in Kenya. At after5, our goal is to create a platform for a network of creatives to share their vision and passion.

Photograph taken by Toby Wesa

This photo book, the first of its kind, brings together a collection of dynamic images, showcasing the work of inspiring photographers.

Photograph taken by Samir Dave

Everyday, everywhere, there are new sights to behold and new experiences to share. this photography book serves to showcase the sights and experiences Kenya has to offer and with it we hope to inspire, surprise and fascinate.

Photograph taken by Sam Stogdale

After5 is about what you do once the sun faints over the horizon, it is about the time you give to the passions you set aside and the dreams you hope to make a reality one day but never get around to doing.

Photograph taken by Georgina Goodwin

100% of the money raised will be to produce this limited first edition coffee table book. It will be produced in large format 240mm x 240mm and on high quality 170gsm silk paper with a hard cover UV varnish finish. There will be approximately 170 pages of 100 images.

Our hope is that this book will reach the corners of the globe and inspire readers. Portions of the printed books will also be distributed to schools all over Kenya, with the hopes of inspiring our kids to see kenya through our eyes.

Photograph taken by Thandiwe Muriu

On behalf of all the contributors, I would ask you to take a leap of faith and support this project. However small your contribution, it will go a long way to make this a reality. It's time we share the incredible talent and vision of these photographers with a wider audience. This is the platform and now is the time. 

Please share this project with your friends and family and feel free to contact me if you have any comments or questions.

Thank you, Christina.

www.after5.co.ke

info@after5.co.ke

Photograph taken by Neil Thomas

story:
Our Story  

HI MY NAME IS GARRY WILLIAMS, AND I'M A FREELANCE PHOTOGRAPHER FROM COVINGTON, GA. NOT TO LONG WE MOVED HERE FROM SUNNY SAN DIEGO, CA. SO THAT WE COULD BE CLOSER TO OUR FAMILYS AND START A HOME BASE PHOTO STUDIO, WE BEEN HERE ABOUT 5 YEARS TO THE DAY AND ALL WAS GOING OK UNTIL THE ECONOMY TANK ON JUST ABOUT EVERYONE. AS FOR ME I WAS JUST STARTING TO SEE SOME LIGHT AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL WHEN THINGS TOOK A TURN FOR THE WORST, BUT I GUESS YOU ALREADY KNOW ABOUT ALL THAT STUFF, SO I'LL TELL YOU WHY I'M LOOKING FOR SOME ASSISTANCE WITH MY CAMPAIGN, NOT TO LONG AGO THE LOVE OF MY LIFE (MY WIFE) STARTED TO HAVE SOME PAIN IN HER STOMACH, SO BEING THAT SHE ALREADY WORK IN ONE OF THE HOSPITAL HERE (ROCKDALE MEDICAL CENTER) SHE HAD SOME TEST DONE, SO WHEN IT CAME TIME TO FIND OUT WHAT THE PROBLEM WAS , THE DOCTOR TOLD US IT WAS POSTIVE FOR COLON CANCER, I ALMOST WENT INTO SHOCK, I DON'T THINK I WAS READY TO HEAR THAT, BUT IT WAS HER CO-WORKER WHO CAME TO HER SIDE THAT GOT ME THROUGH THAT DAY, IF NOT FOR THEM BEING THERE, I DON'T KNOW WHAT I WOULD HAVE DONE, THAT WHEN THINGS STARTED TO MOVE A LITTLE BIT FAST FOR ME, BECAUSE I JUST KNEW THAT I WAS GOING TO TAKE HER HOME THAT DAY AFTER HER OUT PATIENT PROCEDURE. THAT NEVER HAPPEN, BECAUSE THE DOCTOR INFORMED UE SHE HAD TO BE ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL AND HAVE SURGERY THE NEXT DAY, SHE STAYED IN THE HOSPITAL FOR A WEEK AND THEN WAS DISCHARGED . THEN IT WAS NOT OVER SHE HAD TO START TAKING CHEMO, NOW THAT IS OVER SHE IS BACK TO WORK. 

 

The Impact

THE IMPACT THAT THIS STORY MAY HAVE ON OTHERS IS TO SEE THAT YOU CAN GO THROUGH ANY THING IF YOU BELIEVE IN YOURSELF AND YOU CAN GET YOUR LIFE BACK ON TRACK.  

What We Need & What You Get

AT THIS POINT I REALLY DON'T KNOW WHAT TO SAY, I'M JUST DEALING WITH IT ONE DAY AT A TIME, AS FAR AS MONEY IS CONCERN I DON'T WANT TO SEEM LIKE I'M BEGGGING ANYONE, BECAUSE WE ALL KNOW THAT TIME ARE HARD FOR ALL OF US, AND THIS IS NOT THE FIRST TIME AND IT WILL NOT BE THE LAST, NOW GETTING TO WHAT WE NEED THE MONEY FOR IS TO GET MY WIFE BACK ON TRACK, SHE WAS OUT OF WORK FOR 8 WEEKS AND THERE WAS NO WORKER COMP COMING IN BECAUSE SHE WAS UNDER THE DEADLINE AND THE INSURANCE ONLY PAYED A SMALL PART OF THE $38,000 THOUSAND DOLLARS IT WOULD HAVE COST IF SHE DIDN'T HAVE THE INSURANCE FROM WORK. NOW THE BILLS HAVE US BACKED UP IN A CORNER. WHICH I HAVE FAITH THAT SOMETHING WILL COME ALONG, THAT'S WHY I'M DEVERTING MOST OF THE LITTLE MONEY THAT I GET FROM THE PHOTOGRAPHY TO GET US BACK TO BEING NORMAL. NOW THE OTHER THING I LIKE TO DO IS ONCE WE GET THINGS BACK IS KEEP THE CAMPAIGNS GOING SO THAT MAYBE SOMEONE ELSE CAN GET THEM SELF BACK TOGETHER, BECAUSE I THINK ONCE SOMEONE STARTS SOMETHING OTHER PEOPLE GET EXCITED THEN THEY TOO WANT TO HELP. YOU KNOW WE LIVE IN A WORLD NOW WERE PEOPLE A LITTLE DOWN ON THEMSELF. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I COULD NOT WAIT TO GET TO THIS PART OF THE STORY, BECAUSE I HAVE A LITTLE STORY THAT I WOULD LIKE TO SHEAR WITH MY FELLOW CAMPAIGNER, I WAS OUT AND ABOUT DOING MY DAILY ROUTINE, WHEN I STOP BY THE BANK TO TAKE CARE OF SOME BUSINESS, WHEN I STARTING THINKING ABOUT LETTING SOMEONE ELSE KNOW ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN I WAS ABOUT TO EMBARK ON, SO I APPROCH ONE OF THE TELLER AND STARTED TELLING HER ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN AND SHE TOLD ME THAT SHE HAD ONE OF HER FAMILY MEMBER PASSED AWAY FROM THE SAME THING THAT MY WIFE HAD, SO WE TALK A LITTLE BIT, THEN I ASKED HER WOULD SHE BE INTERESTED IN HELPING ME OUT WITH MY CAMPAIGN, SHE TOLD ME TO BRING HER SOME MORE INFORMATION WHEN I COME BACK TO THE BANK, AND I WALK OUT  SAYING THAT WAS NOT HARD AT ALL, SO NOW I FEEL FULLY ENGAGED AT THIS POINT  AND THAT MUST BE A GOOD SIGN.

I COULD NOT WAIT TO GET TO THIS PART OF THE STORY, BECAUSE I HAVE A LITTLE STORY THAT I WOULD LIKE TO SHEAR WITH MY FELLOW CAMPAIGNER, I WAS OUT AND ABOUT DOING MY DAILY ROUTINE, WHEN I STOP BY THE BANK TO TAKE CARE OF SOME BUSINESS, WHEN I STARTING THINKING ABOUT LETTING SOMEONE ELSE KNOW ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN I WAS ABOUT TO EMBARK ON, SO I APPROCH ONE OF THE TELLER AND STARTED TELLING HER ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN AND SHE TOLD ME THAT SHE HAD ONE OF HER FAMILY MEMBER PASSED AWAY FROM THE SAME THING THAT MY WIFE HAD, SO WE TALK A LITTLE BIT, THEN I ASKED HER WOULD SHE BE INTERESTED IN HELPING ME OUT WITH MY CAMPAIGN, SHE TOLD ME TO BRING HER SOME MORE INFORMATION WHEN I COME BACK TO THE BANK, AND I WALK OUT  SAYING THAT WAS NOT HARD AT ALL, SO NOW I FEEL FULLY ENGAGED AT THIS POINT  AND THAT MUST BE A GOOD SIGN.

story:
Clustrr is for people who are passionate about photography & fashion, who appreciate the art and who believe that their photos deserve a better place than being sandwiched between selfies & kittens on social supermarkets.

We’ve crafted Clustrr to be an experience where an artist gets appreciation, finds inspiration and discovers opportunities for monetisation.

If you shoot with a DSLR, or got a professional portfolio done, you are serious about it.

We invite you to become a part of this creative community and join the celebration of great photos, inspiring stories and amazing people like you

A unification of Beautiful Photography, Professional portfolio & Functional Marketplace; Clustrr offers a number of features for these creatives:

And all the social stuff..

What We Need

After a year out of our own pockets, we have managed to push Clustrr to a public beta. Most of the money has gone into its development and running costs. 

We believe we made something useful, and have many ideas to make it great. But with the limited funds and growing costs, we will not be able to sustain our development, operations and marketing beyond Feb 2015.

At the moment our current running costs are around $1700-2000/mth. However we want to put some more money in our marketing efforts to be able to reach out to our target audience.

We want to keep Clustrr free, and ad-free for the creatives to join and find work. 

Thus we want your support in:

Raising Funds

We would love your backing to keep our efforts going. Whatever support we receive from you will be spent towards making Clustrr better and reach out to more people.

Attracting Talent

  • Post jobs, assignments, casting calls & requirements for Photographers, Retouchers, Models, Actors, Fashion Designer, Hair & Makeup Artists and more on Clustrr Marketplace. 

  • If you are, or know any professional or upcoming creative, join and get your friends to join us. 

  • If you blog, tweet, sketch or doodle, write about us. We may be able to put you on our blogs.

  • Follow us on Twitter, Facebook, G+, Tumblr, Medium, Crunchbase, Angelist

  • Become our beta tester and provide feedback on making Clustrr truly "crafted for creatives".

What You Get

As our supporter, we would be creating a section in our About us page with credit to your Names and Link. (for any amount over $25) 

We have identified 4 spots on our homepage to feature our Top Supporters. They can be your business logos with URLs or your Clustrr profile card

The Impact

With your backing, we believe that Clustrr will become a truly beautiful & professional place for everything Photography, Fashion & Media.

Risks & Challenges

The people who have joined us appreciate our effort and see the potential in the product. But with our limited budget, currently we are not able to spend much on marketing and thus despite of making a good product are not able to spread a word to our target audience 

We are trying all avenues we know of to promote ourselves organically; from writing blogs & PRs to being active on social networks & answering questions, but we need more exposure to attract talent and populate marketplace with job assignments.

Some lasting thoughts..

Everyday millions of pictures gets liked, shared and disappear

People follow People who follow more People

Social is saturated, Professional fragmented

If your life is about photos, Your Photos should do More

story:
Short Summary

My name is Shoog McDaniel and I am a fat, genderqueer artist and photographer living in Gainesville, Florida. It has long been my dream to produce a tangible book of my photography, because I feel that it is important to have visual representations of the beauty and strength that queers hold. This book brings together the natural flora and fauna of Florida and the magic of southern queers, and I am so excited to be able to finally share it!
This is not a fundraiser, it is a way for me to allow people to preorder the book so I can place a bulk order.  You will receive the book in a few months (hopefully by new years but definitely by feb 2016 at the latest), once the campaign has ended and I receive the printed books.
Queer and gender non-conforming bodies are extremely under-represented in the media, and I hope this photo book can be a small way to change that. The book includes 45 photos of queer people in nature as well as quotes and thoughts from myself and participants about the importance of nature in our lives. 
The price of the books was calculated by adding the literal cost of printing each book, plus the cost of shipping, plus a small bit more to pay myself for some of the hours spent working on this.

What We Need & What You Get

$25 is the earlybird special! First 25 get the book for $25. One book!  

$27 is one book w/o shipping (pick it up from me in Gainesville, Florida)

$30 bux is the cost of one book (including shipping). 

$35 is a signed book.

$5 for a postcard of an image from the book!

Contact me about shipping to countries outside of the US



To check out this project on instagram, follow : @shooglet or search the hashtag #radqueersinnature. Check out my upcoming project #radqueerspaces.


Please share with anyone who may be interested!

story:
A little about me...

My name is Harvey Pullings, Jr. I'm a Chicago based filmmaker and photographer, born and raised on the south side of Chicago. I have always been interested in the urban landscapes that are often deemed gritty, crime ridden or "economically depressed," as environments that exist outside of majority interest. Having grown up in both Chatham and Princeton Parks (a neighborhood not too far from Evergreen Park), I gained a diverse perspective of how Black citizens' lifestyles compare and contrast. The dynamics of religion, violence and social activity offer a complex look how we function and exist, and how influential the perspective is to our identities. 

When I graduated from Columbia College Chicago, I wrote and directed my thesis short film, To Those with Good Intent, that followed the story of a young Black man from the south side of Chicago, whose aspirations for a well paying job and independence, leads him into violent dilemma. Now, I'm turning my attention to showcasing the real life environment and atmosphere, that I have both grown up in and am inspired by.

Concrete & Cashmere is my first photo exhibit, presented by Raw Chicago Artists, held at the Metro Chicago on July 18th. The "Cashmere" of the showcase is the beauty of the urban visuals. The presentation Black citizens as more than statistic, and "criminal," but rather strong, beautiful and majestic.

The "Concrete" is the gritty, enforced beauty of my shoots with tattoo model, Kyla DeLacerda. All works that represent my view of Chicago's multi-faced Identity and aesthetic.

This campaign is for donations and/or ticket sales, which will contribute towards my exhibit.  Your contributions will allow you to attend the event, seeing my work as well as other amazing Chicago artists, and help support myself as I continue my career as a photographer and filmmaker. You're helping shape my future.

 

Why am I asking for funding?

I have 20 pre-sale tickets for sale, that is a requirement for my participation in the event - with a deadline of July 11th. As of today, I have sold only 2. I'm asking for $400.00 (that is 22.00 for my remaining 18 tickets). Your donation towards my campaign, will go towards a pre-sale ticket(s) for the show. You are not required to attend, as the ticket can be given to someone who'd like to, or your donation can simply be 22.00 (or however much you choose to donate) that assists me in taking part in this opportunity.

(Note: Indiegogo requires the minimum for crowdfunding to be 500.00. This is a figure pursued only by the site's guidelines. The figure needed is $400.00. The extra 100.00 will be allocated to printing materials for the event, as well as photo framing)

Where are your funds going?

All funds  go to Raw Artists Chicago, an organization that showcases artists of various media, giving them platforms to show their artistry within large scale events. Ticket sales go towards the necessities of making these showcases possible for each artist. If my financial goal is not met by the time of this campaign's end, Raw Chicago  requires for all artists to contribute their available ticket sales, even after the deadline given. Proof can and will be given to all contributors, to prove the usage of funds.

 

The Impact of your Contribution (and the Event)

The inner city is home to several people, who are often void of many positives. Whether they are an aspiring artist, or simply citizens of their communities, the need for identity and representation is vital. My photography is intended to showcase the beauty, humanity and vulnerability of the people within the community, as well as the possibilities for those who live there.

The last major project I worked on To those with Good Intent (see above for synopsis) was accepted into several film festivals, both domestic and international. The film won the 2017 Audience Choice Award at the Chicago International Reel Shorts Film Festival, and was recently submitted to Chicago Southside Film Festival. 

These topics within my art is both personal and passionate, and this exhibit will continue this brand of urban identity and expression.

 

Why I need your help 

Art is collaborative. It is not single person medium, and public showcases require the same integrity as the art it displays. My projects are professional and intimate, so the way the audience receives my work is as pivotal as their investment. Your donation is helping me make my first outing within a photo exhibit not only a success, but an event that will help my career and brand grow. You're not just donating, you're taking part in writing a chapter in presenting Chicago's diverse visuals, lifestyles and perspectives.

 

...and if you can't donate

Share this page campaign. Get the word out, follow my instagram (@the79thstreetkid), check out my portfolio and read my essays on cinema, narratives and imagery. Your comments on my pictures and film projects are just as important as donations. The more people who see these visuals and participate in my projects, the more my work will continue to grow.

-Harvey Pullings, II

story:
Short Summary

As family and good friends do when awful things befall a loved one, we’re rallying around Sean with the goal of raising the capital needed to replace what was taken and make our friend whole again. In addition, we are including funds to cover insurance and the processing fees that indiegogo charges to conduct the fundraiser.

Please consider joining this campaign among friends and family and GIVE WHAT YOU CAN.

While ANY donation amount is more than acceptable, Sean has agreed to several incentives which will allow you to benefit from Sean's gift including: 

 

LEVEL ONE: $25.00

Receive (1) 5x7 print from the Landscape Series on Flickr.


LEVEL TWO: $ 100.00

Receive (1) signed limited edition 11 x 14 magazine size print from the Landscape Series on Flickr. 

Important: 7 Day Advance Notice Needed

 

LEVEL THREE: $ 250.00

Receive (2) signed 16 x 20 limited edition prints from the Landscape Series which includes Amsterdam / Berlin / Cholulua in the Valley of Mexico.

*Note: Please review photos on the Flickr page and MAKE SELECTIONS IN THE COMMENTS. RON WORTHY WILL TAKE NOTE.

Important: 7 Day Advance Notice Needed

 

LEVEL FOUR: $ 500.00

FULL DAY PORTRAIT SESSION (in studio).

Bring your wardrobe, your grooming products and your beautiful face. All day personal photo session with Sean Toussaint in his studio. You will receive a disc with five of your favorite high resolution images including retouching. 

Important: 7 Day Advance Notice Needed

PICNIC BARBECUE

Food, glorious food! Sean Toussaint will cook a barbecue package which feeds (30) people. You can choose (3) meats and (3) sides from the menu listed below.

Meat: Pull pork,pork spareribs, jerk chicken, smoked BBQ chicken, whole smoked turkey (12lb), beef ribs, beef tailgate burgers.

Sides: “Award winning” Mac N Cheese, Country Greens (either vegetarian or with smoked turkey), dirty rice, BBQ beans (red kidney beans), potato salad, fried corn.

* Includes disposable cutlery, plates and napkins.

* Must be picked up.

Important: 7 Day Advance Notice Needed


LEVEL FIVE: $ 1000.00

PRIVATE 4 WEEK DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY COURSE.

One on one private instruction with Sean Toussaint. One day a week, 4 hrs per day. Learn the basics in digital photography such as digital capture, photoshop and printing.

PRIVATE 5 WEEK B/W TRADITIONAL PHOTOGRAPHY COURSE.

One on one private instruction with Sean Toussaint. One day a week, 4 hours per day. Learn basics in B/W photography such as proper exposure, how to develop b/w film and printing from negatives (darkroom instruction).

Note: Please review photos on the Flickr page and MAKE SELECTION IN THE COMMENTS SECTION.  RON WORTHY WILL TAKE NOTE.

PLEASE KEEP IN MIND THAT ANY DONATION WILL BE GLADLY APPRECIATED.  HOWEVER, ONLY THOSE AT THE LEVELS ABOVE WILL RECEIVE PERKS.

story:
Introducing In a World of Their Own: Carnival Dreamers and Makers, Photographs by Maria Nunes

A lot of what I see and hear when people talk about “Traditional Mas” or “Traditional Carnival” in Trinidad and Tobago is a view from the outside. A few years ago, a seed started to grow within me of wanting to share the stories of the people I photograph from their perspective as much as I could – to share a view of Carnival traditions from the inside. I wanted to celebrate the extraordinary Carnival men and women I’ve been privileged to photograph and to share the deep wonder, admiration and respect I have for them. As such, my photography has become a conscious decision to bear witness to their commitment and creativity, which is often lost or overlooked, within the wider canvas of Carnival. The more I’ve immersed myself in the many worlds of Carnival, the more I’ve seen that, through photography, I have a responsibility to the people who live for Mas: to be one of their storytellers.

In a World of Their Own travels through time and space in Carnival, from the preparation beforehand, to the last rays of light at dusk on Carnival Tuesday. You’ll join me on my route through Belmont, the Savannah, East Port of Spain and South Quay. You’ll find yourself in Paramin, Perseverance Village, Arima, Moruga, Mayaro, Debe and San Fernando. And throughout this journey you’ll have voices to contemplate too. Juxtaposed with the photographs are extracts of interviews done over the past seven years with several of the dreamers and makers pictured in the book. These are woven in in such a beautiful way! They offer a precious glimpse of the depth of our Carnival dreamers and makers’ passion for Mas, while a beautiful and lyrical essay by Shivanee Ramlochan contributes important thoughts on archive and document. In a World of Their Own is, therefore, not just a book of photographs, but an invitation to the reader to look and think beyond the apparent surface.

In a World of Their Own
Approximately 300 colour and black and white images
10" x 10"
216 pages, 150gsm silk paper
Smyth-sewn (lay flat) binding
Hardcover, with paper wrap

Features:
An introductory essay by Shivanee Ramlochan, with excerpts of interviews conducted with Steffano Marcano, Adrian Young, Alan Vaughan, Kemoi Harper, Tekel ‘Salti’ Sylvan, Shynel Brizan, Stephanie Kanhai, Lionel Jagessar Senior, Desmond Noel, Etienne Charles, Narcenio ‘Señor’ Gomez, Ronald Alfred, Tracey Sankar-Charleau, Darlington ‘Boysie’ Henry, Narrie Approo, Anderson Patrick, and Wendell Manwarren.
 

 

Why This Book is Needed, and Why Now

Although I’ve been photographing Trinidad Carnival’s dreamers and makers for ten years now, something shifted when I started sharing those images on social media. A lot of people started liking and commenting on the images but, more importantly to me, they started sharing them. One of my friends recently told me that my photographs have helped to revive interest in traditional Carnival in Trinidad. I certainly hope that’s true, and I can only imagine that this book would take that interest further and deeper, to help us better understand our culture, and to help set in stone the important role that these individuals play. Documenting is important – it’s a fantastic thing to be able to hold up a mirror to someone; to help them to see themselves and, through images, to pay respect to the work that they are doing.

With this book, I hope to offer an alternative perspective to the repeated – and often unfounded – narrative that Carnival traditions are dying and are mainly the concern of an older generation. To be sure, there is an ongoing struggle to keep some traditions going, but to mindlessly cut and paste that clichéd mantra is to miss the reality that so many Carnival artists today are a younger generation bringing new energy to the Carnival space and actively taking the mantle of responsibility for cultural vibrancy from their elders. Their work is the marriage of new ideas and tradition and their creativity is a real-time response within Carnival as a whole. They need our active support and encouragement.

 

 

Where I'm At

I’ve had a book on my mind for the past couple of years and I recently decided to get going on making it a reality. Over the past eight months I’ve engaged a fantastic, T&T based art book publisher, Robert & Christopher Publishers (R&C), and I’ve raised 75% of the book’s total budget through the generous support of Republic Bank Limited (through their Power to Make a Difference programme), Massy Foundation, Ministry of Community Development, Culture and the Arts, and Monlo Music Ltd. I’ve spent months going through thousands of images with the book’s editors, Melanie Archer and Mariel Brown, in order to make the final cull of the 300 photographs that appear in In a World of Their Own. We’ve spent a lot of time and care as well in getting the interviews transcribed and selecting excerpts. Trinidadian writer, Shivanee Ramlochan, has paid beautiful tribute to the dreamers and makers pictured here, and has written so wonderfully on the importance of archive. In a World’s designer, artist Richard Mark Rawlins has made beautiful sense of so much content and, inspired by the people in the book, has even added a bit of his own brilliant, original artwork that will enhance the stories being told. As I write this, the book is a few short days from being sent to our selected printer in Canada. In a World of Their Own will be launched on April 24th, 2018 in Port of Spain, as part of the annual NGC Bocas Lit Fest.
 

 

What I Need and What You Get

One of the most important things to me, in terms of the physical aspects of this book, is that it is beautifully printed and bound, ensuring its durability, especially as I envision it not as a book you look at once and put down, but something that you would want to revisit time and time again. Taking those factors into account, I made the decision to print the book outside of T&T – in Canada, to be precise – in order to achieve the highest possible quality printing and lay-flat, sewn binding, which will help increase the book’s durability and ease of reading. Those standards have, of course, increased the cost as well, but I believe them to be very important.

I’ve covered all of the book’s other expenses to date, but now I need to raise the cost of printing. If you live in Trinidad & Tobago, you would understand how difficult it currently is to get foreign exchange. Launching an Indiegogo campaign for In a World of Their Own is a great way for me to get the foreign currency I need to cover my printing bill. It also provides a fantastic outlet through which I can track and fulfill advance orders of the book.

By contributing to this Indiegogo campaign, you will help bring to completion this important document of Trinidadian culture and Carnival, as well as show your support for numerous Carnival dreamers and makers, my work, and also local publishing.

Your contributions can come in several forms:
1. Advance orders
2. Advance orders with added perks
3. Perks
4. Donations

I’m pleased to be able to offer limited edition prints of a few of my most loved images as perks. I’ll be releasing those in the the coming weeks. Please check out the column at the right of this text to have a look at the available perks, and follow me on Facebook and Instagram for updates!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t in a position to contribute financially or to pre-order books, please put in a good word for my project and post, tweet and share this page, every bit helps (and use the Indiegogo share tools whenever possible).

If you have any questions, please send them my way, I'd be glad to hear from you! Email me at nunesie2@gmail.com

Thanks again for all your support.


 

About the Book's Team

Maria Nunes
www.marianunes.com
Maria Nunes is a photographer and producer with special interest in the documentation of cultural heritage and the work of performing artists through both still images and filmmaking. She is in her element when immersed in capturing imagery of the traditional carnival arts, the work of steelbands, or in documenting the creative process of artists. Maria has worked closely with the National Archives and the Carnival Institute on heritage-based projects, and is a co-founder of Calabash Foundation for the Arts.

Maria's work is significantly influenced by her love of music – she collects early calypso, string band and big band recordings of Trinidad and Tobago, as well as traditional folk and kalinda songs.

Maria is also a former Junior World golf champion and Sportswoman of the Year. In 1980 she received the Hummingbird Medal, Gold, and in 2012, on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of Independence, she was named one of the 50 legends of sport in Trinidad and Tobago.

 

Writer: Shivanee Ramlochan
www.shivaneeramlochan.com
Shivanee Ramlochan is a Trinidadian poet, arts reporter and book blogger. She is the Book Reviews Editor for Caribbean Beat Magazine. Shivanee also writes about books for the NGC Bocas Lit Fest, the Anglophone Caribbean's largest literary festival, as well as Paper Based Bookshop, Trinidad and Tobago's oldest independent Caribbean specialty bookseller. She is the deputy editor of The Caribbean Review of Books. Shivanee's first book, Everyone Knows I Am a Haunting, was published in 2017 by Peepal Tree Press.

 

Publisher: Robert & Christopher Publishers
www.robertandchristopher.com
Robert & Christopher Publishers (R&C) is a Trinidad-based art book imprint. R&C’s primary concern in its art series is to produce quality books that document and elucidate our Caribbean story, as seen through the eyes of Caribbean artists and photographers. R&C aims to produce the highest quality of relevant art books that will be accessible to a wide reading and creative audience in Trinidad and Tobago, the Caribbean and internationally.

In addition to In a World of Their Own: Carnival Dreamers & Makers, Photographs by Maria Nunes, Robert & Christopher has also published: See Me Here: A Survey of Contemporary Self-Portraits from the Caribbean, Pictures from Paradise: A Survey of Contemporary Caribbean Photography, Che Lovelace: Paintings 2004 – 2008, Meiling: Fashion Designer and Barbara Jardine: Goldsmith.
story_txt:
Introducing In a World of Their Own: Carnival Dreamers and Makers, Photographs by Maria Nunes

A lot of what I see and hear when people talk about “Traditional Mas” or “Traditional Carnival” in Trinidad and Tobago is a view from the outside. A few years ago, a seed started to grow within me of wanting to share the stories of the people I photograph from their perspective as much as I could – to share a view of Carnival traditions from the inside. I wanted to celebrate the extraordinary Carnival men and women I’ve been privileged to photograph and to share the deep wonder, admiration and respect I have for them. As such, my photography has become a conscious decision to bear witness to their commitment and creativity, which is often lost or overlooked, within the wider canvas of Carnival. The more I’ve immersed myself in the many worlds of Carnival, the more I’ve seen that, through photography, I have a responsibility to the people who live for Mas: to be one of their storytellers.
In a World of Their Own travels through time and space in Carnival, from the preparation beforehand, to the last rays of light at dusk on Carnival Tuesday. You’ll join me on my route through Belmont, the Savannah, East Port of Spain and South Quay. You’ll find yourself in Paramin, Perseverance Village, Arima, Moruga, Mayaro, Debe and San Fernando. And throughout this journey you’ll have voices to contemplate too. Juxtaposed with the photographs are extracts of interviews done over the past seven years with several of the dreamers and makers pictured in the book. These are woven in in such a beautiful way! They offer a precious glimpse of the depth of our Carnival dreamers and makers’ passion for Mas, while a beautiful and lyrical essay by Shivanee Ramlochan contributes important thoughts on archive and document. In a World of Their Own is, therefore, not just a book of photographs, but an invitation to the reader to look and think beyond the apparent surface.
In a World of Their OwnApproximately 300 colour and black and white images10" x 10"216 pages, 150gsm silk paperSmyth-sewn (lay flat) bindingHardcover, with paper wrap

Features:An introductory essay by Shivanee Ramlochan, with excerpts of interviews conducted with Steffano Marcano, Adrian Young, Alan Vaughan, Kemoi Harper, Tekel ‘Salti’ Sylvan, Shynel Brizan, Stephanie Kanhai, Lionel Jagessar Senior, Desmond Noel, Etienne Charles, Narcenio ‘Señor’ Gomez, Ronald Alfred, Tracey Sankar-Charleau, Darlington ‘Boysie’ Henry, Narrie Approo, Anderson Patrick, and Wendell Manwarren. 

 
Why This Book is Needed, and Why Now
Although I’ve been photographing Trinidad Carnival’s dreamers and makers for ten years now, something shifted when I started sharing those images on social media. A lot of people started liking and commenting on the images but, more importantly to me, they started sharing them. One of my friends recently told me that my photographs have helped to revive interest in traditional Carnival in Trinidad. I certainly hope that’s true, and I can only imagine that this book would take that interest further and deeper, to help us better understand our culture, and to help set in stone the important role that these individuals play. Documenting is important – it’s a fantastic thing to be able to hold up a mirror to someone; to help them to see themselves and, through images, to pay respect to the work that they are doing.
With this book, I hope to offer an alternative perspective to the repeated – and often unfounded – narrative that Carnival traditions are dying and are mainly the concern of an older generation. To be sure, there is an ongoing struggle to keep some traditions going, but to mindlessly cut and paste that clichéd mantra is to miss the reality that so many Carnival artists today are a younger generation bringing new energy to the Carnival space and actively taking the mantle of responsibility for cultural vibrancy from their elders. Their work is the marriage of new ideas and tradition and their creativity is a real-time response within Carnival as a whole. They need our active support and encouragement.
 

 
Where I'm At
I’ve had a book on my mind for the past couple of years and I recently decided to get going on making it a reality. Over the past eight months I’ve engaged a fantastic, T&T based art book publisher, Robert & Christopher Publishers (R&C), and I’ve raised 75% of the book’s total budget through the generous support of Republic Bank Limited (through their Power to Make a Difference programme), Massy Foundation, Ministry of Community Development, Culture and the Arts, and Monlo Music Ltd. I’ve spent months going through thousands of images with the book’s editors, Melanie Archer and Mariel Brown, in order to make the final cull of the 300 photographs that appear in In a World of Their Own. We’ve spent a lot of time and care as well in getting the interviews transcribed and selecting excerpts. Trinidadian writer, Shivanee Ramlochan, has paid beautiful tribute to the dreamers and makers pictured here, and has written so wonderfully on the importance of archive. In a World’s designer, artist Richard Mark Rawlins has made beautiful sense of so much content and, inspired by the people in the book, has even added a bit of his own brilliant, original artwork that will enhance the stories being told. As I write this, the book is a few short days from being sent to our selected printer in Canada. In a World of Their Own will be launched on April 24th, 2018 in Port of Spain, as part of the annual NGC Bocas Lit Fest. 

 
What I Need and What You Get
One of the most important things to me, in terms of the physical aspects of this book, is that it is beautifully printed and bound, ensuring its durability, especially as I envision it not as a book you look at once and put down, but something that you would want to revisit time and time again. Taking those factors into account, I made the decision to print the book outside of T&T – in Canada, to be precise – in order to achieve the highest possible quality printing and lay-flat, sewn binding, which will help increase the book’s durability and ease of reading. Those standards have, of course, increased the cost as well, but I believe them to be very important.
I’ve covered all of the book’s other expenses to date, but now I need to raise the cost of printing. If you live in Trinidad & Tobago, you would understand how difficult it currently is to get foreign exchange. Launching an Indiegogo campaign for In a World of Their Own is a great way for me to get the foreign currency I need to cover my printing bill. It also provides a fantastic outlet through which I can track and fulfill advance orders of the book.
By contributing to this Indiegogo campaign, you will help bring to completion this important document of Trinidadian culture and Carnival, as well as show your support for numerous Carnival dreamers and makers, my work, and also local publishing.
Your contributions can come in several forms:1. Advance orders2. Advance orders with added perks3. Perks4. Donations
I’m pleased to be able to offer limited edition prints of a few of my most loved images as perks. I’ll be releasing those in the the coming weeks. Please check out the column at the right of this text to have a look at the available perks, and follow me on Facebook and Instagram for updates!

 
Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t in a position to contribute financially or to pre-order books, please put in a good word for my project and post, tweet and share this page, every bit helps (and use the Indiegogo share tools whenever possible).
If you have any questions, please send them my way, I'd be glad to hear from you! Email me at nunesie2@gmail.com
Thanks again for all your support.

R&C aims to produce the highest quality of relevant art books that will be accessible to a wide reading and creative audience in Trinidad and Tobago, the Caribbean and internationally.
In addition to In a World of Their Own: Carnival Dreamers & Makers, Photographs by Maria Nunes, Robert & Christopher has also published: See Me Here: A Survey of Contemporary Self-Portraits from the Caribbean, Pictures from Paradise: A Survey of Contemporary Caribbean Photography, Che Lovelace: Paintings 2004 – 2008, Meiling: Fashion Designer and Barbara Jardine: Goldsmith.
campaign_city: Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago

story:
THE STORY

In April 2015, I left my well-paying job and comfortable life in Singapore to go to New York to take on an unpaid internship. I had been working for a few years as a photographer but felt that I needed to sharpen my craft. So, I looked to the Big Apple. I wanted to know what caused the gap between the work in Singapore and those that I had seen from the U.S. After five months in New York, I spent another four in Los Angeles immersing myself in film sets to expand my lighting skill.

Between those two cities, I also travelled around the region. I started my backpacking trip in the Caribbean in Cuba and subsequently went to Haiti, Peru, Bolivia, Chile, Mexico and a few other countries. I wanted to experience cultures that were different from mine and learn from their way of life. My perspectives were expanded each day by the different environments and people that I interacted with. I also photographed extensively during this period, trying to form my unique way of seeing the world.

WAKING UP IN STRANGE PLACES is borne out of my desire to make those experiences and memories tangible for myself, and hopefully for others as well.

THE ZINE

What is a zine? Well for a start, it is neither a book or a magazine. I'd like to think that it is somewhere in between. The lack of definition frees me to make something more experimental and create a different reading experience. Actually, I think it's just my way of taking myself less seriously. ;)

The zine is designed by Do Not Design (the irony, I know). We went through a long process of conceptualization to bring different ideas and themes together. The final design has 67 images and some writing from my journal that are condensed into five unique chapters. They are bound together by a special material (you have to buy it to know!). This material allows the reader to re-arrange the chapters in any way that they want. Therefore, there is no fixed way of viewing or displaying the zine. The viewer decides their own version of my journey.

The zine also includes some postcards of my photographs. I sent out postcards frequently when I was on the road and I hope that the reader will do the same. There are also pages which are large enough that they can be displayed as prints and hung on the wall. All in all, the zine is bigger, deeper and larger than the sum of its parts.

THE PERKS

Just for this crowdfunding period, I am also offering prints for the images in the zine at a special price. Wait, didn't you say the pages of the zine is large enough to be hung on the wall? Yes, you definitely can! But if you want a high quality fine art print to display in your home/studio, then this perk is for you. You can choose any image from the zine that you fancy and I will personally print the image to ensure the ink lands on the fine art paper the way it should.

If you want a portrait session, I am also happy to offer it at a discounted rate when you get it with the zine. I've photographed for some famous international companies and magazines, so I think I'm quite legit. ;)

THE PHOTOGRAPHER

(And this is where I speak in third person.)

Juliana Tan is a Singapore-based editorial and commercial photographer.

Her ability to illuminate her subjects has landed her images on publications such as The New York Times, Financial Times, Condé Nast Traveler, and she has also photographed for Western Union, Rolls-Royce, United Overseas Bank, PURE Group and many others.

In 2012, Juliana was nominated as top 10 emerging photographers in Singapore by platform.sg. She is a featured photographer for Canon EOS World (Singapore) and winner of the grant prize (photo story) at Kuala Lumpur International Photo Awards in 2013. Her films have been screened at many film festivals, including DocuWest Film Festival (Colorado, USA), 3rd Salaya Documentary Festival (Thailand), 6th Indie Documentary Festival (Singapore) and won Outstanding Documentary at Hong Kong Global Chinese Universities Student Film Festival and Best Editing at Singapore Short Films Award.

While not on assignment, Juliana enjoys exploring new cities to learn about history and culture. Follow her work here and her travel adventures here.

THANK YOU :)

You have no obligation to buy a copy of the zine, but if you do, I thank you for coming along this journey with me. And I hope in some little ways you get inspired and moved by the photographs and musings.

And if you don't buy it, we shall never again be frie.... just kidding, we will still be friends!

story:
Mission Statement: 

I want to provide my amazing clients with excellent photography services at a reasonable price and in a manner that is comfortable and convienent. Help me continue to do that!

The Short Story: 

I have a trusty Nikon I love that hasn't done me wrong yet. However, it's 8 years old which is ancient in the land of technology. I really really really need a new camera so I can expand this little photography business of mine while still keeping my old camera as a reliable back-up for just-in-case.  

I've picked out a Nikon 7100 and new lens - it's substantially better than what I have (24 megapixels vs just 10!), yet still offers the best bang for the buck.  I think it will serve me well and meet my needs as I grow my business.  

And the Big Picture:

Our family has been going through tough times - no sense hiding that fact as most of our friends know my husband has been out of salaried work for over 2 years. Do the math...Cash flow is not great. I can't afford to purchase the camera I need before my spring season gets into high gear. Any funds raised during this time above and beyond my camera needs will go directly to the mortgage and other household expenses. 

So here's The Plan:

Essentially, you'll be paying for your photo session(s) in advance. If you know you always book with me in the fall then please consider paying up front now and we will do your family shoot in the fall - I'll give scheduling preference to those who have paid in advance.  As usual, I'm fairly flexible with schedules and available to travel most anywhere around the Metro DC area; Philadelphia is also an option for event photography.

You aren't in the DC area? Guess what?! I'm including scanning services in my pricelist. Maybe, like me, you were married a million years ago and all your wedding pics are on film. Or maybe you have old family photos you'd like to archive digitally for future generations.  Now's the time! I have an excellent Epson V500 photo scanner that also scans slides and negatives. A wonderful idea for anniversaries and reunions, too.

Photography Pricelist:

  • $50 - Headshot special - perfect for your LinkdIn page, acting career or business work. We can shoot onsite or outside, anywhere. Includes 2-3 digital images for your use.
  • $85 - 30 min photo session - great for families with small kids! Preferably outdoors in your yard or a park. Includes CD of digital images for your use.
  • $125 - 60 min photo session - great for larger families, newborns, couples/engagements. Includes CD of digital images for your use.
  • $150 - 60 min of event photography with CD of images. 
  • $225 - 2 hours of event photography with CD of images
  • $300 - 3 hours of event photography with CD of images
  • $1000 - Wedding special! Up to 8 hours of photography services. I'm a bargain, I know. I've only done 2 and I've loved every minute. Happy to offer myself up as a discount - essentially you are paying for my time - day of and in the "darkroom" afterwards sorting and editing. I have references and portfolios I can share if you are interested, please feel free to contact me before purchasing.
  • All sessions will be posted online in a password-protected gallery and professional quality prints can be purchased a la carte at any time (I definitely recommend this for any large prints, especially those being hung on the wall).
  • Prices will be going up for the first time ever in April! Act now for the best deal and use your purchase later.

Scanning Pricelist:

  • $50 - up to 25 images (photo, slide or negative)
  • $100 - up to 50 images (photo, slide or negative)
  • $200 - up to 100 images (photo, slide or negative) 
  • $150 - photo book - let me organize and work with you to create an archival quality photo book with blurb.com (additional copies of your finished book can be purchased at cost - consider making a book of family pictures going back generations and printing copies for each of your cousins for the holidays...)
  • All images can be mailed/fedexed to me and I will return them and a CD of digital images the same way I received them.  Local peopled - happy to arrange drop off/pick up. 

And that's it. I love photography. I love capturing moments and telling stories and taking pictures that will pass the test of time.  I love you all in advance for helping me continue this journey!

                                                                                                Best, 

                                                                                                     Katie

story: I am looking to recover from a photography mishap.
story_txt: I am looking to recover from a photography mishap.

story:
Hey!

    My name is Serge Levin and I've been taking photos of people on the streets of Philadelphia for the past 6 months. Recently, I've been kindly offered to exhibit my work at the Gershman Y  located at the intersection of Pine and Broad st. in Philadelphia. The exhibit will take place in the month of April, with the opening reception scheduled for April 3rd, to which you are invited.

    The amazing, large space in the heart of Philadelphia is free, but there will be a significant printing + framing costs (I will also be providing food!), so if you enjoy my photography and would like to support it, here is one way to do so. 

    But above all, while I'd love for this exhibit to be funded by this campaign, the much more valuable thing to me would be seeing friends and family come out for an evening in Philadelphia. 

    Feel free to share this campaign with anyone you feel may be interested in coming out for a night of art; we hope to see you there!


PS. you can see my ongoing work on flickr
story_txt: Hey!    My name is Serge Levin and I've been taking photos of people on the streets of Philadelphia for the past 6 months. Recently, I've been kindly offered to exhibit my work at the Gershman Y  located at the intersection of Pine and Broad st. in Philadelphia. The exhibit will take place in the month of April, with the opening reception scheduled for April 3rd, to which you are invited.    The amazing, large space in the heart of Philadelphia is free, but there will be a significant printing + framing costs (I will also be providing food!), so if you enjoy my photography and would like to support it, here is one way to do so.     But above all, while I'd love for this exhibit to be funded by this campaign, the much more valuable thing to me would be seeing friends and family come out for an evening in Philadelphia.     Feel free to share this campaign with anyone you feel may be interested in coming out for a night of art; we hope to see you there!PS. you can see my ongoing work on flickr

story:
Hello, my name is Murat and I’m from Istanbul, Turkey.  I’m an aspiring photographer who is trying to establish myself in the city.  I’ve been playing music for many years but nothing excites me more now than taking photos and developing my skills as a photographer.  I’ve been taking photos using only my phone’s camera in the past several months and have gotten some good results.  My friends and family have encouraged me with their positive feedback and this has made me feel very motivated to continue.


After several months of taking photography seriously I have started to become limited by my camera. 

I believe in my photos, and am passionate about developing my work.  I hope to pursue my interest at professional level in the near future. I don’t need an expensive camera - all I need is one that can take higher resolution photos for print. 

After searching for several weeks I found the CANON POWERSHOT G16, which is a relatively cheap camera of good value.  I know that I don’t have a big story for you, but would be very grateful for any contributions.  Please take a look at my photos on Instagram and you can decide if you want to help me out. 

instagram.com/heuvn

Thank you so much.

story:
In another reality, I think I was a busker. I actually picked up the guitar at roughly the same time I discovered photography. The camera stuck, the guitar not so much. But in some mirror universe, who knows? Perhaps this is why I enjoy photographing them so much, why I find them such fascinating subjects—it’s a look into the Path Not Taken.

On a deeper level, though, I think my fascination stemmed from envy. Buskers are modern day vagabonds, minstrels singing for their supper. They were faced with a choice and said, “I’d rather lead  a humble, dollar-to-dollar life doing something I love than a comfortable, secure life doing something I don’t.” I was faced with the same choice and said “Well, I’ve got bills to pay so I have to keep the day job. How about nights and weekends?” 

So yeah, I was a bit jealous. I wanted nothing more than to quit and go full-time with my photography, but I couldn’t pull the trigger. Even after eight years of cubicle hell, I couldn’t bring myself to leave the security of my job.

Then I got laid off.

I’ve heard that most people feel lost when they’ve been laid off. I felt relieved. Just like that, I didn’t have a job to hide behind anymore. And the very company I’d been trying to muster the courage to leave just paid me a bunch of money to go away. This was my moment to put up or shut up and see if I really had what it took to do this full time.

So I dove right in. And while momentum was slow to build, it was getting better and it was looking more and more like there might be a viable career in photography for me, after all. It was gonna be a slim first few months (and thank god for severance), but it was looking promising.

Then someone stole my gear bag.

I was photographing my friends one night and took my eyes off my camera bag just long enough for someone to make off with over $4,000 worth of equipment. Insurance covered some (barely half) but there’s still a pretty big chunk missing.

When I got laid off I saw it as an opportunity. To make an earnest go of a career in photography. In the same way, this theft is a challenge. To see if I’ve got what it takes. If my photography can’t even pay for itself, how can it pay for me?

The Campaign

Over the last four months or so I’ve been photographing buskers in and around New York City for a photoblog called The New York Freeharmonic. I’ll be printing a collecting some of my favorite photos as well as previously-unpublished shots and new content shot exclusively for the book and am turning to Indiegogo to see if I can at least sell enough of them to cover the loss of my gear. 

The Book

The book will be 100 pages, hardbound, printed on a silk semi-gloss 100lb paper that is both acid and lignin-free through Mixbooks. Each copy will be signed and numbered, and come with a photo postcard, perfect for use as a bookmark. The book will be 8”x6” in size, though if by some chance more than 250 books are ordered, the price point will drop and I’ll be able to afford to print them at 11”x8.5” at only a slight cost on my part.

In addition to the books I am also offering matted prints, discounted photo shoots (stop by my site to see samples of my work!), and more. Rewards will ship in November, making them great gift ideas.. Photo books are perfect gifts for those people you don’t wanna bother puzzling over gift ideas for but still want to get them something “nice.” Like in-laws.

The Goal

The goal of $2,500 is the break-even point. Hit that and at the very least the campaign doesn't wind up costing me money. From there, any extra pledged money will mean I'll be able to offer more to the donors—a few extra pages in the book, maybe. Or a free 8x10 print. And of course, hitting the magic "250" number means I'll be able to print the books at a bigger size.

Other ways to help

Even if you're unable to contribute right now, any and all help in getting the word out would be more than enough. Tweet or Facebook me, send the link (http://igg.me/at/nyfh) to anyone you think might be interested. It really does make a great gift. And it's autographed, too!

story:
We are professional modeling agents and foundes of a modeling community known as TopModelGroup.com, and we launch crowdfunding for online photo studio.  Professional photographers and amateur ones can direct and control their photo shoots from anywhere in the world. Working prototype has already been developed.

IMAGINE A ROBOTIC ONLINE PHOTO STUDIO

  • High end DSLR cameras remotely controlled by you from your web browser
  • Top class 85 mm lenses
  • You can move and rotate the cameras in any of 8 directions

  • Professional photo models, remotely posing for you in the studio
  • Professional lighting presets
  • Voice and text chat makes it easy to direct model

Imagine yourself sitting on a sofa at your home and remotely performing a professional photo shoot.

Unleash your creativity, create professional photos and videos with ease.

LIMITED OFFER

When you contribute from this page, you get a LIFETIME premium membership, as well as LIFETIME free priority acess, etc (see perks in the right column). We will never make this offer again after the campagn is funded.

FEATURES

1.  Shoot photo and HD video

2.  Direct model via text or voice chat

3.  Use super smooth green screen background for further chroma keying (i.e. you can substitute your own background image or video later, see the video above for example).

4.  You hold full legal rights and copyright for all shots you make (model signs model release, which is sent to you by request)

5.  Select from 5 background and lighting presets

6.  Remotely enable wind machine, smoke machine and bubble machine

7.  Additional accessories, such as a message board, where the model can write any text you want or draw something in real time (e.g. your logo).

8.  Order your text or a logo to be printed on model’s t-shirt (for additional $15 to cover expenses for the t-shirt itself and printer ink)

FREE & PAID ACCESS

1.  Two studios are free to use for everyone (“Lite Studios”). Every free studio is equipped with 2 DSLR cameras and one HD camcorder.

Each pair of DSLR cameras in every Lite and Pro studio includes Canon EOS Mk 3 and Nikon D800, both equipped with best 85mm lenses (Canon  EF 85 f 1.2 L II and Nikon 85mm f/1.4G AF-S Nikkor)

Users wait in a queue to take control over the robotic camera of their choice. The photo session lasts for 15 minutes.

Our backers will always have priority access to the Lite studio, see our perk descriptions.

Features 1-4 from the list above are available for users of the Lite Studio, features 5-8 are not available to them.

2.  Two other studios are paid ("Pro Studios"); each studio equipped with 2 DSLR cameras and 1 HD camcorder. All 8 features from the list above are available for paid studio users.

The cost of the paid access to the Pro Studio is $150 per hour... for everyone else. But not for you! Because if you back us now, you get everything.



PERKS FOR CONTRIBUTORS

·  Lifetime priority access to the free Lite Studio (see above). Pay nothing and shoot top class models with high-end cameras.

·  Up to 70% lifetime discount for using the Pro studio, which offers even more professional options.

70% off for the Pro usage means that you only pay $45 per hour of a photo shooting, including studio, professional lighting, high-end photo cameras, lenses, additional acessories and beautiful photo models. 

Just compare it with prices of your local studio (without models, cameras, etc).

·  Some perks also include Premium photographer membership  on TopModelGroup.com

You can find specific perk descriptions in the right column at the top of this Indiegogo page.


USE CASES

1.  Build your skills. Practice shooting with professional lighting (select from different lighting presets), using high-end cameras and lenses. Professional photo models are posing for you, practice directing them by voice or via text chat.

2.  Create commercials: Shoot professional photos and videos for selling on stock sites.

3.  Easily and quickly shoot any promotional pictures and videos: models can wear a t-shirt with your logo (printed in 10 minutes by your request); models can draw your logo or custom text on a message board in real time; models can say something about your company when you shoot video; you can shoot models against a green background to replace it later with your own background picture or video (chroma keying).

4. For novice photographers: create a professional-looking portfolio.

5.  Feel the difference between high-end Canon and Nikon cameras, equipped with the best lenses. This will promote your further professional growth.

TECHNICAL 

1.  Set camera settings via tethering (aperture, ISO, white balance, etc) or use automatic settings

2.  Create your custom presets for camera settings to use them next time.

3.  Perform a photo shoot from a web browser on any computer or mobile device (Apple and Android devices support is pending).

4. Store the resulting files on our server to download or edit them later



CONTRIBUTOR PRIORITY LEVELS WHEN ACCESSING THE FREE "LITE" STUDIOS

As you can see in our perk descriptions, every contributor has his own priority level. 

1. Priority Level 1 means, whenever you stand in a queue, you immediately become the first in the queue, unless other Level 1 users are already standing there.

Level 1 also allows you to schedule your future photo shoots in the Lite Studios, by selecting from available dates and hours.

2. Priority Level 2 means, whenever you stand in a queue, you will immediately become the first in the queue, unless other Level 2 users are already standing in the queue, and unless any Level 1 user decides to stand there. In this case you will be standing immediately after them.

3. Priority Level 3 means that whenever you stand in a queue, you will immediately become the first in the queue, unless other Level 3 users are already standing in the queue, and unless any Level 2 or Level 1 user decides to stand there. In this case you will be standing immediately after them.


NO FLAKE MODELS, NO MODELS BEING LATE

Many photographers are familiar with a situation when they schedule a photo shoot with a model, but the model is being late or even flakes (no call, no show). Preparing the studio and sitting and waiting for a model that never shows... Ugh, what may be worse?

In the online studio studio all models will always be available as scheduled and schedule of every model will be publicly viewable on site.


REFERRAL PROGRAM

Help us by spreading the word via email and social media. After the campaign is funded we'll refund your contribution in accordance with credits you earned referring people.

In short: if you successfully refer a friend to contribute to the campaign, then we will refund you $50. If you refer one more friend – we will refund you another $50. And so on.

If the amount of credits you earned has covered the sum of your pre-ordered package (so you get a complete refund), any further referral $ will be credited to your account. After the studio goes live, you can spend these $ for getting the PRO studio access. And don’t forget, as a contributor, you also have up to 70% Pro discount, as well as you have a priority access to the free Lite Studios.

Please note that contributors cannot receive referral credit for referring themselves. Of two contributors, only one can be the 'referrer' and receive campaign credit for the other's contribution.  Refunds will be made and credits applied once the campaign is over.

How to participate in the referral program:
It’s simple. Log in to your Indiegogo account . Be sure to use the same account you used when you contributed your Remote Studio Package. Then, look below our main video at the top of this page for buttons to share and copy your unique URL. Start sharing!

Need more information?  We have created detailed instructions here.


WHAT WE ALREADY HAVE

Software:
1.  We have already developed the program code to control Pan-Tilt heads and vertical/horizontal motorized sliders from computer.
2. We have the tethering code to remotely set camera settings, obtain a live-view from the camera, release camera shutter, download files, etc. For both Canon and Nikon.
3. We have a streaming server and browser client to perform a low-latency streaming of the camera's live view to your browser through the web, and control the camera. It is reliable and proven to work with a very low latency even if you're in USA or Australia when the studio is in Europe.

Hardware:
1. We have already tested third-party pan-tilt heads for this system. They work fine, they are reliable and not expensive.
2. We performed some testing for vertical/horizontal sliding of the entire system (will be mounted on vertical and horizontal rails). Not ideal yet, but OK.
3. All devices (motors, lighting) are interfaced with Raspberry Pi via Arduino (single-board microcontroller, intended to make building interactive objects or environments more accessible).


Human:
1. We very well know how to manage the development of the technical part of the project, as we have experience in managing software development and microcontroller/robotic development.
2. At the same time, being modeling agents we have the full understanding of working with photo models.
3. Finally, we have top class photo models ready to work for affordable rates. This will allow us to keep prices stated above for the Pro studio, and even provide free access to the Lite studio. See more information about this below, in the Q&A section.

WHAT WE NEED

Software:
1. We need to implement a web interface to flawlessly control the local code mentioned above (both positioning and tethering) via the web.
2. We need to build the website: designing the layout, managing user accounts, managing access permissions to different studios, queuing and scheduling access to free studios, priority access for contributors, etc. This is possibly the most trivial part, but at the same time the most boring and expensive stage of the software part of the project.

Hardware:
As said above, we still need some working over the horizontal/vertical sliding system. 

Other:
We need a photo studio itself including:

  1.  Placement - we are going to acquire ownership of the estate property to get rid of rental fees, because this will significantly reduce the price of the service for end users. Therefore it will also be more profitable to us, so this is a win-win solution.
  2.  Equipment for the studios.

QUESTIONS & ANSWERS

1.  How many photo studios are planned?

At first, we will start with four photo studios located in the adjacent rooms of the same building. If we’ll see the service is demanded, we will increase the number of studios, as we don’t feel lack of photo models.

2.  The life cycle of the shutter of a camera is limited. How often will you replace cameras in a studio? This might be costly.

While testing our business model, we revealed that the most active and tireless photographers take about 10 shots per minute during a 30-minutes photo session. The production cost of one shot in terms of the resource of a shutter is calculated as $0.016 per shot (the average market price of Canon 5D Mk3, $2400, divided by the life cycle of a shutter claimed by the company - 150,000 actuations). For Nikon D800 costs are even lower. Therefore, in terms of camera’s resources the cost of production of one hour of the most intensive shooting is 10*60*0.016=$9.6. This sum pays off by additional paid services. Also, we carry on negotiations with potential sponsors - photo equipment vendors interested in supporting the project if it proves to be demanded.

3.  Professional models working in two free photo studios and two low-cost ones – sounds good, but how you are going to pay them? What is the source of the funds?

We are the founders of the TopModelGroup.com portal, model agents recruiting and training models. Among other countries, we also work in several developing economies where hourly rates are much lower (several and even dozens of times) than in US, Europe and other developed countries. Such countries are Moldova, Ukraine, Byelorussia, which is geographically located in Europe, but are actually developing economies with average monthly salary about $400.

After finishing training and before signing an international contract (that means earning real money), our every model must complete a 6-month probation. During this period they get a salary typical to the country they live in. At the same time, they are already top-class models passed through our hard training and possessing stunning looks. Due to the same reason we don’t have to overpay to such specialists as make up artists and hair stylists. Our first photo studio will be opened in one of such countries, and further in other countries too.

4.  Ok, hiring even the best models is not expensive for you. But what about rental fees for a photo studio? They are still high. How can you keep prices low and even more – offer free services as well?

We plan to acquire ownership of the photo studio, because this will allow us to get rid of monthly rental fees and therefore minimize prices for end users. Thanks God, real estate costs are low in the countries we are talking about comparing with USA or Europe.

Free studios are funded by paid studios.

5.  What if you won’t receive backing in full?

All promised bonuses for our backers will remain valid. Partial funding means we will embody our idea step by step. Instead of four studios, we will stop on just two (one Lite and one Pro). The entire process may slow down, but we'll complete it anyway.

6.  What if you will see more backing than you ask?

In that case we will equip more photo studios, not just four, in proportion to received funding in order to supply the demand and grant our bonuses to all contributors faster.
